NN as universal approximator (L1, Aug 28 - L2, Aug 30)
  • Input (e.g. images) ‚Üí black box ‚Üí output (e.g. captions)
  • Connectionist machine - models of neurons functioning in human‚Äôs brain
    • Opposed to Von Neumann machines ( processing unit ‚Üî memory (program, data))
    • NN as a program = connection between units (also define memory)
  • The McCulloch & Pitts model (1943) - a logical calculus of the ideas immanent in nervous activities
    • can compose Boolean functions
    • can compose real-values functions
  • Hebbian learning ‚Üí Fundamentally unstable
    • Stronger connections will enforce themselves
    • No notion of ‚Äúcompetition‚Äù
    • No reduction in weights
    • Learning is unbounded
  • Rosenblatt‚Äôs perceptron

    ‚Üí provide a learning algorithm

    • Boolean tasks
    • Update the weights whenever the perceptron output is wrong
    • Proved convergence for linearly separable classes

Alan Turing‚Äôs Connectionist model (1948): Learnable networks that could potentially be trained to model any Boolean function

  • If neuron x repeatedly triggers neuron y, the synaptic knob connecting x to y gets larger.

Mathematically, wxy=wxy+Œ∑xyw_{xy} = w_{xy} + \eta xywxy‚Äã=wxy‚Äã+Œ∑xyÔªø

Logic: fire if combined input exceeds threshold

Y={1¬†if¬†‚àëiwixi‚àíT‚â•00¬†elseY = \begin{cases} 1 & \text{ if } \sum_i w_i x_i - T \geq 0 \\ 0 & \text { else} \end{cases}Y={10‚Äã¬†if¬†‚àëi‚Äãwi‚Äãxi‚Äã‚àíT‚â•0¬†else‚ÄãÔªø

where d(x)d(x)d(x)Ôªø = desired output in response, y(x)y(x)y(x)Ôªø = actual output

MLP

‚Üí Simplest MLP is a step-function across a hyperplane

for x=[x1,‚Ä¶,xN]T‚ààX‚äÜRNx = [x_1,\dots,x_N]^T \in X \subseteq \R^Nx=[x1‚Äã,‚Ä¶,xN‚Äã]T‚ààX‚äÜRNÔªø

Note: Single-layer MLP cannot compute XOR gate

A neural network can represent any function provided it has sufficient capacity (width & depth)

  • Universal classifiers
  • Composing complicated ‚Äúdecision‚Äù boundaries

    ‚Üí Increasing the number of sides reduces the area outside the polygon that have N2<‚àëiyi<N\frac{N}{2} < \sum_i y_i <N2N‚Äã<‚àëi‚Äãyi‚Äã<NÔªø

    ‚àëiyi=N(1‚àí1œÄarccos‚Å°(min‚Å°(1,r‚à£x‚àíxc‚à£)))\sum_i y_i = N\left(1- \frac{1}{\pi} arc\cos \left(\min\left(1, \frac{r}{|x-x_c|}\right)\right)\right)‚àëi‚Äãyi‚Äã=N(1‚àíœÄ1‚Äãarccos(min(1,‚à£x‚àíxc‚Äã‚à£r‚Äã)))Ôªøwhere xcx_cxc‚ÄãÔªø is center of circle

    ‚áí Compose any arbitrary figure with a number of circles (more accurate with greater number of smaller circles)

    ‚áí Compose arbitrary functions in any number of
    dimensions! ‚Äì Even with only one hidden layer as sums of scaled and shifted cylinders

  • Deep structure ‚Äì The input is the ‚Äúsource‚Äù, the output nodes are ‚Äúsinks‚Äù, ‚Äúdepth‚Äù denotes longest path from source to sink
  • Single layer hidden network will require 2N‚àí12^{N-1}2N‚àí1Ôªø perceptron in a hidden layer to represent NNNÔªø Boolean variables
  • For a deep network, it will only requires 3(N‚àí1)3(N-1)3(N‚àí1)Ôªø perceptrons ‚áí Linear in N!!!
    • An XOR needs 3 perceptrons (2 layers)
    • Can be arranged in only 2log‚Å°2N 2\log_2 N2log2‚ÄãNÔªø layers
  • What if we have less than 2log‚Å°2N2\log_2 N2log2‚ÄãNÔªø layers?
  • Narrow layers can still pass information to subsequent layers if the activation function is
    sufficiently graded
    • But will require greater depth, to permit later
      layers to capture pattern
  • The capacity of a network:
    • Information or Storage capacity: how many patterns can it remember
    • VC dimension
      • bounded by the square of the number of weights in the network
  • More analytical results
    • [Valient et al., ICML ‚Äò14] A polynomial of degree n requires a network of depth (log‚Å°n)2(\log n)^2(logn)2Ôªø
    • [Mhaskar et al., ‚Äò16] all functions that can be expressed as a binary tree

Size of MLP << size of truth table

  • Largest irreducible DNF

    ‚Üí requires 8 perceptrons

Optimal depth?

‚Üí‚åä(N+2)28‚åã \left\lfloor \frac{(N+2)^2}{8}\right\rfloor‚åä8(N+2)2‚Äã‚åãÔªø neurons in 2nd hidden layer (quadratic, not exponential)

‚Üí because data ‚ààR2\in \R^2‚ààR2Ôªø

‚Üí for general case of NNNÔªø mutually intersecting hyperplanes in DDDÔªø dims, we will need O(ND(D‚àí1)!)\mathcal{O}\left(\frac{N^D}{(D-1)!}\right)O((D‚àí1)!ND‚Äã)Ôªø weights (assume N>>DN>>DN>>DÔªø)

‚Üí Other activations

Radial Basis Functions
  • radial symmetry, instead of linear symmetry
  • can compose cylinder-like outputs with just a single unit with appropriate choice of bandwidth Œ≤\betaŒ≤Ôªø (or activation
    function)
    • As opposed to units for the linear perceptron
How to train a NN (L3, Sep 4 - L8, Sep 20)

Learn a NN

Estimate parameter WWWÔªø from sample data XdataX_{data}Xdata‚ÄãÔªø

Problem: g(X)g(X)g(X)Ôªø is unknown

‚áí Sample di=g(Xi)+œµid_i = g(X_i) + \epsilon_idi‚Äã=g(Xi‚Äã)+œµi‚ÄãÔªø

‚áí The empirical error (risk)

  • Assume network architecture is sufficient for such a fit
  • Assume unique output dddÔªø at any XXXÔªø
  • Hopefully the resulting function is also correct where we don‚Äôt have
    training samples

Task: binary classification (correct: error = 0; wrong: error = 1)

Learning the classifier: Minimizing the count of misclassifications

  • Individual neurons represent one of the lines that compose the figure (linear classifiers)
    • Must know the desired output of every neuron for every training instance, in
      order to learn this neuron.
    • The linear separators must combine to
      form the desired boundary

‚áí At least exponential (in inputs) time complexity!!!

y={1¬†if¬†‚àëi=1NwiXi+b‚â•00¬†o.w.y = \begin{cases}1 & \text{ if } \sum_{i=1}^N w_i X_i+b \geq 0\\ 0 & \text{ o.w.} \end{cases}y={10‚Äã¬†if¬†‚àëi=1N‚Äãwi‚ÄãXi‚Äã+b‚â•0¬†o.w.‚ÄãÔªø

  • Boundary ‚àëi=1NwiXi+b=0\sum_{i=1}^N w_i X_i+b = 0‚àëi=1N‚Äãwi‚ÄãXi‚Äã+b=0Ôªø
  • Want to learn W=[w1‚Ä¶wN]TW = [w_1 \dots w_N]^T W=[w1‚Äã‚Ä¶wN‚Äã]TÔªø, and bbbÔªø given (X,y)(X,y)(X,y)Ôªø pairs

Convergence

  • Guaranteed to converge after (RŒ≥)2\left(\frac{R}{\gamma}\right)^2(Œ≥R‚Äã)2Ôªø misclassifications (i.e. iterations) if classes are linearly separable where
    • RR RÔªø is length of longest training point
    • Œ≥\gammaŒ≥Ôªø is the best case closest distance of a training point from the classifier
  • When classes are not linearly separable, it is not possible to find a separating hyperplane
    • No ‚Äúsupport‚Äù plane for reflected data
    • Some points will always lie on the other side

    ‚áí Perceptron algorithm will never converge!!!

Optimization

  • Greedy algorithms
    • ADALINE (Adaptive linear element) [Hopf and Widrow, 1960]
      • z=‚àëiwixiz = \sum_i w_i x_iz=‚àëi‚Äãwi‚Äãxi‚ÄãÔªø, y={0,z<01,z‚â•0y = \begin{cases} 0, & \quad z<0\\ 1, & \quad z\geq 0 \end{cases}y={0,1,‚Äãz<0z‚â•0‚ÄãÔªø
      • Loss(x)=12(d‚àíz)2‚áídLdwi=‚àí(d‚àíz)xiLoss(x) = \frac{1}{2} (d-z)^2 ‚áí \frac{d L}{dw_i} = - (d-z)x_iLoss(x)=21‚Äã(d‚àíz)2‚áídwi‚ÄãdL‚Äã=‚àí(d‚àíz)xi‚ÄãÔªø
      • Gradient descent update rule: wi=wi+Œ∑(d‚àíx)xiw_i = w_i + \eta(d-x) x_iwi‚Äã=wi‚Äã+Œ∑(d‚àíx)xi‚ÄãÔªø

    • MADALINE (Multiple ADALINE)

    ‚áí Effective for small networks

    ‚áí Too expensive for large nets

‚Üí small change in weight can result in non-negligible changes in output with the perceptron ‚áí no indication of which direction to update the weights

‚Üí individual neurons‚Äô weights can change significantly without changing overall error

Solution: estimate parameters using gradients descent

  • Requirements for learnability
    1. Continuous varying activation (differentiable)
      • The perception (step function) is non-differentiable

      ‚áí Logistic regression model

      • Data is not linearly separable

      P(Y=1‚à£X)=11+e‚àíxP(Y=1|X) = \frac{1}{1+e^{-x}}P(Y=1‚à£X)=1+e‚àíx1‚ÄãÔªø ‚Üê sigmoid function

    1. Continuous varying error function (differentiable)

    div(f(X;W),g(X))={0,f(X;W)=g(X)L(f,g)>0,f(X;W)‚â†g(X)div(f(X;W),g(X)) = \begin{cases} 0, & f(X;W)=g(X)\\ L(f,g)>0, & f(X;W) \neq g(X) \end{cases}div(f(X;W),g(X))={0,L(f,g)>0,‚Äãf(X;W)=g(X)f(X;W)ÓÄ†=g(X)‚ÄãÔªø is differentiable w.r.t fffÔªø

  • Properties of gradient
    • Derivative of y=f(x)y = f(x) y=f(x)Ôªø (scalar)
      • Steepness of the curve at xxxÔªø
      • Larger ‚à£f‚Äô(x)‚à£|f‚Äô(x)|‚à£f‚Äô(x)‚à£Ôªø ‚Üí the function is increasing or decreasing more rapidly
    • Derivative of scalar function of vector argument
      • x=[x1,‚Ä¶,xD]T\mathbf{x} = [x_1, \dots, x_D]^Tx=[x1‚Äã,‚Ä¶,xD‚Äã]TÔªø is a vector

    where ‚àáXy=[‚àÇy‚àÇx1,‚Ä¶,‚àÇy‚àÇxD]\nabla_X y = \left[ \frac{\partial y}{\partial x_1}, \dots, \frac{\partial y}{\partial x_D} \right]‚àáX‚Äãy=[‚àÇx1‚Äã‚àÇy‚Äã,‚Ä¶,‚àÇxD‚Äã‚àÇy‚Äã]Ôªø

    ‚áí gradient is the direction of fastest increase in f(X)f(X)f(X)Ôªø

    • The Hessian of f(x)f(\mathbf{x})f(x)Ôªø

    ‚àáx2f=[‚àÇ2f‚àÇx12‚àÇ2f‚àÇx1‚àÇx2‚Ä¶‚àÇ2f‚àÇx1‚àÇ2‚àÇ2f‚àÇx2‚àÇx1‚àÇ2f‚àÇx22‚Ä¶‚àÇ2f‚àÇx2‚àÇxD‚ãÆ‚ãÆ‚ã±‚ãÆ‚àÇ2f‚àÇxD‚àÇx1‚àÇ2f‚àÇxD‚àÇx2‚Ä¶‚àÇ2f‚àÇxD2]\nabla^2_{\mathbf{x}} f = \begin{bmatrix} \frac{\partial^2 f}{\partial x^2_1} & \frac{\partial^2 f}{\partial x_1 \partial x_2} & \dots &\frac{\partial^2 f}{\partial x_1 \partial 2}\\ \frac{\partial^2 f}{\partial x_2 \partial x_1}& \frac{\partial^2 f}{\partial x^2_2}& \dots & \frac{\partial^2 f}{\partial x_2 \partial x_D}\\ \vdots& \vdots & \ddots& \vdots \\ \frac{\partial^2 f}{\partial x_D \partial x_1}& \frac{\partial^2 f}{\partial x_D \partial x_2}& \dots & \frac{\partial^2 f}{\partial x_D^2}\end{bmatrix}‚àáx2‚Äãf=‚Äã‚àÇx12‚Äã‚àÇ2f‚Äã‚àÇx2‚Äã‚àÇx1‚Äã‚àÇ2f‚Äã‚ãÆ‚àÇxD‚Äã‚àÇx1‚Äã‚àÇ2f‚Äã‚Äã‚àÇx1‚Äã‚àÇx2‚Äã‚àÇ2f‚Äã‚àÇx22‚Äã‚àÇ2f‚Äã‚ãÆ‚àÇxD‚Äã‚àÇx2‚Äã‚àÇ2f‚Äã‚Äã‚Ä¶‚Ä¶‚ã±‚Ä¶‚Äã‚àÇx1‚Äã‚àÇ2‚àÇ2f‚Äã‚àÇx2‚Äã‚àÇxD‚Äã‚àÇ2f‚Äã‚ãÆ‚àÇxD2‚Äã‚àÇ2f‚Äã‚Äã‚ÄãÔªø

    • f‚Äô(x)>0f‚Äô(x) >0f‚Äô(x)>0Ôªø ‚áí increase of f(x)f(x)f(x)Ôªø
    • f‚Äô(x)<0f‚Äô(x) <0f‚Äô(x)<0Ôªø ‚áí decrease of f(x)f(x)f(x)Ôªø
    • f‚Äô(x)=0f‚Äô(x) = 0f‚Äô(x)=0Ôªø ‚áí ‚Äúturning point‚Äù

    Unconstrained minimization of function

    ‚áí Solve XXXÔªø where ‚àáxf(X)=0\nabla_{\mathbf{x}} f(X) = 0‚àáx‚Äãf(X)=0Ôªø

    • ‚àáx2f‚âª0\nabla^2_{\mathbf{x}} f \succ 0 ‚àáx2‚Äãf‚âª0Ôªø (positive eigenvalues) ‚áí local minima
    • ‚àáx2f‚â∫0\nabla^2_{\mathbf{x}} f \prec 0 ‚àáx2‚Äãf‚â∫0Ôªø (negative eigenvalues) ‚áí local maxima
  • Gradient Descent

    Closed form solution of ‚àáxf(X)=0\nabla_{\mathbf{x}} f(X) = 0‚àáx‚Äãf(X)=0Ôªø is not always available ‚áí iterative solution

    Problems:

    • Which direction to step in
    • How big must the steps be
    • Start from initial guess X0X_0X0‚ÄãÔªø
    • Update the guess towards a (hopefully) ‚Äúbetter‚Äù value of f(X)f(X)f(X)Ôªø
    • Stop when f(X)f(X)f(X)Ôªø no longer decreases

    Convergence of GD

    • For appropriate step size, for convex functions GD will always find the minimum.
    • For non-convex functions, it will find a local minimum or an inflection point

Representation

  • One-hot representations

    [cat dog camel hat flower]T^TTÔªø

    • cat: [10000]T[1 0 0 0 0]^T[10000]TÔªø
    • dog: [01000]T [0 1 0 0 0]^T[01000]TÔªø
    • camel: [00100]T [0 0 1 0 0]^T[00100]TÔªø

  • Given a number of ‚Äútraining‚Äù data instances
    • E.g. images of digits, along with information about which digit the image represents

Tasks:

  • Binary classification: Is this a ‚Äú2‚Äù?
  • Multi-class classification: Which digit is this?

‚Üí help with gradient descent

Backpropagation

  • Chain rule

    y=f(g1(x),g2(x),‚Ä¶,gM(x))y = f(g_1(x),g_2(x),\dots, g_M(x))y=f(g1‚Äã(x),g2‚Äã(x),‚Ä¶,gM‚Äã(x))Ôªø, where zi=gi(x)z_i = g_i(x)zi‚Äã=gi‚Äã(x)Ôªø

    Vector calculus

    y=[y1y2‚ãÆyM]=f([z1z2‚ãÆzM])=f(z)‚áíy = \begin{bmatrix}y_1\\ y_2\\\vdots\\y_M \end{bmatrix}= f\left(\begin{bmatrix}z_1\\ z_2\\\vdots\\z_M \end{bmatrix}\right) = f(z) ‚áíy=‚Äãy1‚Äãy2‚Äã‚ãÆyM‚Äã‚Äã‚Äã=f‚Äã‚Äãz1‚Äãz2‚Äã‚ãÆzM‚Äã‚Äã‚Äã‚Äã=f(z)‚áíÔªø Discretize Œîy=‚àázyŒîz\Delta y = \nabla_z y \Delta z Œîy=‚àáz‚ÄãyŒîzÔªø

    where z‚ààRR√ó1z\in \R^{R\times 1}z‚ààRR√ó1Ôªø, y‚ààRL√ó1y \in \R^{L\times 1}y‚ààRL√ó1Ôªø, the Jacobian of yyyÔªø w.r.t zzzÔªø Jy(z)=‚àázy‚ààRL√óRJ_y(z) = \nabla_z y \in \R^{L\times R}Jy‚Äã(z)=‚àáz‚Äãy‚ààRL√óRÔªø.

    z(y)=W(y)+b‚áí‚àáyz=Jz(y)=Wz(y) = W(y)+ b ‚áí \nabla_y z = J_z(y) = Wz(y)=W(y)+b‚áí‚àáy‚Äãz=Jz‚Äã(y)=WÔªø

  • Must remember the intermediate values to compute the derivatives
  • Computing derivatives

  • Compute the divergence Div(Y,d)Div(Y,d)Div(Y,d)Ôªø, where dddÔªø is the desired output
  • Compute ‚àáY(N)Div(.)=(‚àÇDiv‚àÇy1(N),‚Ä¶,‚àÇDiv‚àÇyDN(N))\nabla_{Y^{(N)}}Div(.) =\left( \frac{\partial Div}{\partial y_1^{(N)}}, \dots, \frac{\partial Div}{\partial y_{D_N}^{(N)}}\right)‚àáY(N)‚ÄãDiv(.)=(‚àÇy1(N)‚Äã‚àÇDiv‚Äã,‚Ä¶,‚àÇyDN‚Äã(N)‚Äã‚àÇDiv‚Äã)Ôªø
  • Compute ‚àáZ(N)Div(.)\nabla_{Z^{(N)}}Div(.)‚àáZ(N)‚ÄãDiv(.)Ôªø

    ‚àÇDiv‚àÇzi(N)=‚àÇyi(N)‚àÇzi(N)‚àÇDiv‚àÇyi(N)=fN‚Ä≤(zi(N))‚àÇDiv‚àÇyi(N)\frac{\partial Div}{\partial z_i^{(N)}} = \frac{\partial y_i^{(N)}}{\partial z_i^{(N)}} \frac{\partial Div}{\partial y_i^{(N)}} = f'_N(z_i^{(N)})\frac{\partial Div}{\partial y_i^{(N)}} ‚àÇzi(N)‚Äã‚àÇDiv‚Äã=‚àÇzi(N)‚Äã‚àÇyi(N)‚Äã‚Äã‚àÇyi(N)‚Äã‚àÇDiv‚Äã=fN‚Ä≤‚Äã(zi(N)‚Äã)‚àÇyi(N)‚Äã‚àÇDiv‚ÄãÔªø

Convergence

‚Üí Is backpropagation always right?

‚Üí How well does it learn? How well will it generalize outside training data?

  • [Brady, Raghavan, Slawny, ‚Äô89] Backprop fails to separate where perceptron succeeds!

Unique solution exists for this simple setup

  • wx.1+wy.0+b=uw_x.1+w_y.0+ b =uwx‚Äã.1+wy‚Äã.0+b=uÔªø
  • wx.0+wy.1+b=uw_x.0+w_y.1+ b =uwx‚Äã.0+wy‚Äã.1+b=uÔªø
  • wx.(‚àí1)+wy.0+b=‚àíuw_x.(-1)+w_y.0+ b =-uwx‚Äã.(‚àí1)+wy‚Äã.0+b=‚àíuÔªø

‚áí‚áí‚áíÔªø wx=u,wy=u,b=0w_x = u, w_y=u, b=0wx‚Äã=u,wy‚Äã=u,b=0Ôªø for some uuuÔªø.

‚Üí both backprop and perceptron
algorithms find solutions

  • Perceptron may change greatly upon adding just a single new training instance
    • Makes no errors if possible‚Äì But high variance
    • Can swings wildly in response to small changes to input
  • Backprop is minimally changed by new training instances
    • Prefers consistency over perfection
    • Low-variance estimator, at the potential cost of bias
  • t>>0t>>0 t>>0Ôªø - perceptron may take t2t^2t2Ôªø iteration to find the solution
  • For t>>0t>>0t>>0Ôªø, ‚à£wy‚à£>œµ|w_y|>\epsilon‚à£wy‚Äã‚à£>œµÔªø
    • (1‚àíœµ‚àíœÉ(‚àíwy+b))‚Üí1(1-\epsilon-\sigma(-w_y+b))‚Üí 1(1‚àíœµ‚àíœÉ(‚àíwy‚Äã+b))‚Üí1Ôªø as t‚Üí‚àût‚Üí \inftyt‚Üí‚àûÔªø
    • œÉ‚Äô(‚àíwyt+b)‚Üíexp‚Å°0\sigma‚Äô(-w_yt+b) \overset{\exp}{\rightarrow}0œÉ‚Äô(‚àíwy‚Äãt+b)‚Üíexp0Ôªø as t‚Üí‚àût‚Üí \inftyt‚Üí‚àûÔªø

    ‚áídDiv4dwy=dDiv4db=0‚áí \frac{d Div_4}{dw_y} = \frac{d Div_4}{db} =0‚áídwy‚ÄãdDiv4‚Äã‚Äã=dbdDiv4‚Äã‚Äã=0Ôªø

‚Üí (0,‚àít)(0,-t)(0,‚àít)Ôªø does not change the gradient of the L2 divergence near the optimal solution for 3 points
‚Üí The optimum solution for 3 points is also a broad local minimum (0 gradient) for the 4-point problem!

  • The loss surface
    • Saddle points (slope=0, some of the eigenvalues of Hessian are positive, some are negative) are far more common than local minima
      • Frequency of occurrence exponential in network size
      • Most local minima are equivalent & close to global minimum
      • This is not true for small networks
      • Gradient descent algorithms often get ‚Äústuck‚Äù in saddle points
    • Neural network loss surface is generally not convex (Streetlight effect)
      • KL loss is convex as a function of weights for a single-layer perceptron (for 2-dimensional inputs {(xi,yi)}i‚àà[n]\{(x_i,y_i)\}_{i\in[n]}{(xi‚Äã,yi‚Äã)}i‚àà[n]‚ÄãÔªø), while L2 is not.

Optimization

  • (Convex) optimization
    • GD = iterative algorithm
      • may or may not converge

        • What is optimal Œ∑\etaŒ∑Ôªø?

            F(w)=F(w(k))+F‚Äô(w(k))(w‚àíw(k))+12F‚Äô‚Äô(w(k))(w‚àíw(k))2F(w) = F(w^{(k)}) + F‚Äô(w^{(k)})(w-w^{(k)})+\frac{1}{2} F‚Äô‚Äô(w^{(k)})(w-w^{(k)})^2F(w)=F(w(k))+F‚Äô(w(k))(w‚àíw(k))+21‚ÄãF‚Äô‚Äô(w(k))(w‚àíw(k))2Ôªø

          • wmin=w(k)‚àíF‚Äô‚Äô(w(k))‚àí1F‚Äô(w(k))‚áíŒ∑opt=F‚Äô‚Äô(w(k))‚àí1w_{min} = w^{(k)} - F‚Äô‚Äô(w^{(k)})^{-1} F‚Äô(w^{(k)}) ‚áí \eta_{opt} = F‚Äô‚Äô(w^{(k)})^{-1}wmin‚Äã=w(k)‚àíF‚Äô‚Äô(w(k))‚àí1F‚Äô(w(k))‚áíŒ∑opt‚Äã=F‚Äô‚Äô(w(k))‚àí1Ôªø

      • Multivariate quadratic with diagonal A: F(w)=12wTAw+wTb+cF(\mathbf{w}) = \frac{1}{2} \mathbf{w}^T A \mathbf{w} + \mathbf{w}^T b + cF(w)=21‚ÄãwTAw+wTb+cÔªø (strongly convex function)

        or any differentiable convex objective F(w)‚âàF(w(k))+‚àáwF(w(k))(w‚àíw(k))+12(w‚àíw(k))THF(w(k))(w‚àíw(k)) F(\mathbf{w}) \approx F(\mathbf{w}^{(k)}) + \nabla_{\mathbf{w}} F(\mathbf{w}^{(k)})(\mathbf{w}- \mathbf{w}^{(k)}) + \frac{1}{2} (\mathbf{w}- \mathbf{w}^{(k)})^T H_F (\mathbf{w}^{(k)})(\mathbf{w}- \mathbf{w}^{(k)})F(w)‚âàF(w(k))+‚àáw‚ÄãF(w(k))(w‚àíw(k))+21‚Äã(w‚àíw(k))THF‚Äã(w(k))(w‚àíw(k))Ôªø

        • When AAAÔªø is diagonal: F(w)=12‚àëiaiiwi2+biwi+cF(\mathbf{w}) = \frac{1}{2}\sum_i a_{ii}w_i^2 + b_i w_i + cF(w)=21‚Äã‚àëi‚Äãaii‚Äãwi2‚Äã+bi‚Äãwi‚Äã+cÔªø
          • wiw_iwi‚ÄãÔªø are uncoupled (could optimize each direction independently)
        • For strictly convex, A AAÔªø is always positive definite, and has positive eigenvalues.
        • Vector update rule
          • w(k+1)‚Üêw(k)‚àíŒ∑‚àáwFT\mathbf{w}^{(k+1)} ‚Üê \mathbf{w}^{(k)} - \eta\nabla_{\mathbf{w}} F^Tw(k+1)‚Üêw(k)‚àíŒ∑‚àáw‚ÄãFTÔªø

          (wi(k+1)=wi(k)‚àíŒ∑dF(wi(k))dw)\left(w_i^{(k+1)} = w_i^{(k)} - \eta \frac{d F(w_i^{(k)})}{d\mathbf{w}}\right)(wi(k+1)‚Äã=wi(k)‚Äã‚àíŒ∑dwdF(wi(k)‚Äã)‚Äã)Ôªø

          • Œ∑i,opt=(‚àÇ2F(wi(k))‚àÇwi2)‚àí1\eta_{i,opt} = \left(\frac{\partial^2 F(w_i^{(k)})}{\partial {w_i}^2}\right)^{-1}Œ∑i,opt‚Äã=(‚àÇwi‚Äã2‚àÇ2F(wi(k)‚Äã)‚Äã)‚àí1Ôªøor

          ‚àù1Œªi,Hw\propto \frac{1}{\lambda_{i,H_{\mathbf{w}}}}‚àùŒªi,Hw‚Äã‚Äã1‚ÄãÔªø

          • Convergence is slow if ‚Äúcondition‚Äù number max‚Å°iŒ∑i,optmin‚Å°iŒ∑i,opt>>1\frac{\max_i \eta_{i,opt} }{\min_i \eta_{i,opt} } >>1mini‚ÄãŒ∑i,opt‚Äãmaxi‚ÄãŒ∑i,opt‚Äã‚Äã>>1Ôªø
            • Need ‚Äúcondition‚Äù number ‚âà1\approx 1‚âà1Ôªø for fast convergence
            • The objective function has different eccentricities in different directions ‚áí Resulting in different optimal learning rates for different directions
            • More difficult when the ellipsoid is not axis aligned: the steps along the two
              directions are coupled!

            ‚áí Scale the axes

          ‚Üí Dependence on learning rate

          • GD will oscillate in all directions where Œ∑i,opt<Œ∑<2Œ∑i,opt\eta_{i,opt} <\eta < 2 \eta_{i,opt}Œ∑i,opt‚Äã<Œ∑<2Œ∑i,opt‚ÄãÔªø
          • If Œ∑>2min‚Å°iŒ∑i,opt\eta > 2 \min_i \eta_{i,opt}Œ∑>2mini‚ÄãŒ∑i,opt‚ÄãÔªø, the GD algorithm diverges

          ‚áí make the algorithm very slow due to small learning rate!!

      • Most functions are not strongly convex (if they are convex)
      • Lipschitz smoothness: ‚à£f(x)‚àíf(y)‚à£‚â§L‚à£x‚àíy‚à£|f(x)-f(y)| ‚â§ L|x-y|‚à£f(x)‚àíf(y)‚à£‚â§L‚à£x‚àíy‚à£Ôªø
        • Need not be convex (or even differentiable)
        • Has an upper bound on second derivative (if it exists)
        • Suppose appropriate learning rate (non-divergent), ‚à£f(w(k))‚àíf(w‚àó)‚à£‚àù1k‚à£f(w(0))‚àíf(w‚àó)‚à£|f(\mathbf{w}^{(k)})-f(\mathbf{w}^*)| \propto \frac{1}{k}|f(\mathbf{w}^{(0)})-f(\mathbf{w}^*)|‚à£f(w(k))‚àíf(w‚àó)‚à£‚àùk1‚Äã‚à£f(w(0))‚àíf(w‚àó)‚à£Ôªø if fffÔªø is Lipschitz smooth and convex.

          ‚áí‚à£f(w(k))‚àíf(w‚àó)‚à£‚â§12Œ∑k‚à£f(w(0))‚àíf(w‚àó)‚à£‚áí |f(\mathbf{w}^{(k)})-f(\mathbf{w}^*)| ‚â§ \frac{1}{2\eta k}|f(\mathbf{w}^{(0)})-f(\mathbf{w}^*)|‚áí‚à£f(w(k))‚àíf(w‚àó)‚à£‚â§2Œ∑k1‚Äã‚à£f(w(0))‚àíf(w‚àó)‚à£Ôªø

    • Newton‚Äôs method (Œ∑=1\eta =1Œ∑=1Ôªø)
      • w(k+1)‚Üêw(k)‚àíŒ∑HF(w(k))‚àí1‚àáwFT\mathbf{w}^{(k+1)} ‚Üê \mathbf{w}^{(k)} - \eta H_F (\mathbf{w}^{(k)} )^{-1} \nabla_{\mathbf{w}} F^Tw(k+1)‚Üêw(k)‚àíŒ∑HF‚Äã(w(k))‚àí1‚àáw‚ÄãFTÔªø
      • HF(w(k))H_F (\mathbf{w}^{(k)} )HF‚Äã(w(k))Ôªø is extremely difficult to compute
        • For a network with only 100,000 parameters, the Hessian will have 101010^{10}1010Ôªø cross-derivative terms.
        • Is even harder to invert for its huge size.
        • May not be positive semi-definite for non-convex functions ‚áí algorithm can diverge.
        • Requires additional checks to avoid movement in directions corresponding to negative eigenvalues of the Hessian.

        ‚áí Boyden-Fletcher-Goldfarb-Shanno (BFGS) & ‚Äúlow-memory‚Äù BFGS (L-BFGS)

        • Estimate Hessian from finite differences

        ‚áí Levenberg-Marquardt

        • Estimate Hessian from Jacobians
        • Diagonal load it to ensure positive definiteness

        ‚áí Other ‚ÄúQuasi-newton‚Äù method

      • How to choose learning rate? (since large Œ∑>2Œ∑opt\eta > 2 \eta_{opt}Œ∑>2Œ∑opt‚ÄãÔªø can help to escape local optima when necessary)

        ‚áí Decaying learning rate

        • Linear decay: Œ∑k=Œ∑0k+1\eta_k = \frac{\eta_0}{k+1}Œ∑k‚Äã=k+1Œ∑0‚Äã‚ÄãÔªø
        • Quadratic decay: Œ∑k=Œ∑0(k+1)2\eta_k = \frac{\eta_0}{(k+1)^2}Œ∑k‚Äã=(k+1)2Œ∑0‚Äã‚ÄãÔªø
        • Exponential decay: Œ∑k=Œ∑0e‚àíŒ≤k\eta_k = \eta_0e^{-\beta k}Œ∑k‚Äã=Œ∑0‚Äãe‚àíŒ≤kÔªø, where Œ≤>0\beta > 0Œ≤>0Ôªø

        Common approach for training NN (repeat until we‚Äôre happy with the performance):

        1. Train with a fixed learning rate until loss stagnates
        1. Œ∑‚ÜêŒ±Œ∑\eta ‚Üê \alpha \etaŒ∑‚ÜêŒ±Œ∑Ôªø where Œ±<1\alpha < 1Œ±<1Ôªø
    • RProp (Resilient propagation)

      Compute the derivative in the new location

      • If the derivative has changed sign
      • Return to the previous location: ùë§^=ùë§^+‚àÜùë§\hat{ùë§}=\hat{ùë§}+‚àÜùë§w^=w^+‚àÜwÔªø
      • Shrink the step: ‚àÜùë§=ùõΩ‚àÜùë§ ‚àÜùë§= ùõΩ‚àÜùë§‚àÜw=ùõΩ‚àÜwÔªø (Œ≤<1\beta <1Œ≤<1Ôªø)
      • Take the smaller step forward ùë§^=ùë§^+Œîw\hat{ùë§}=\hat{ùë§} +\Delta ww^=w^+ŒîwÔªø

    • QuickProp
      • Treats each dimension wiw_iwi‚ÄãÔªø independently
      • Approximates the second derivative through finite differences

        where D(wi(k),wi(k‚àí1))=F‚Äô(wk(k))‚àíF‚Äô(wi(k‚àí1))Œîw(k‚àí1)D\left(w_i^{(k)},w_i^{(k-1)}\right) = \frac{F‚Äô\left(w_k^{(k)}\right) - F‚Äô\left(w_i^{(k-1)}\right)}{\Delta w^{(k-1)}}D(wi(k)‚Äã,wi(k‚àí1)‚Äã)=Œîw(k‚àí1)F‚Äô(wk(k)‚Äã)‚àíF‚Äô(wi(k‚àí1)‚Äã)‚ÄãÔªø is finite-difference approximation of Hessian F‚Äô‚Äô(wi(k)‚à£wj(k),j‚â†i)F‚Äô‚Äô\left(w_i^{(k)}|w_j^{(k)},j\neq i\right)F‚Äô‚Äô(wi(k)‚Äã‚à£wj(k)‚Äã,jÓÄ†=i)Ôªø

      • For training NN, Div‚Äô(wl,ij(k))Div‚Äô(w_{l,ij}^{(k)})Div‚Äô(wl,ij(k)‚Äã)Ôªø can be computed using backpropagation and used to estimate the Hessian.
    • Nestorov‚Äôs method

      Momentum update:

      1. Computes the gradient step at the current location

        Œîw(k)=Œ≤Œîw(k‚àí1)‚àíŒ∑‚àáwF(w(k‚àí1))T\Delta \mathbf{w}^{(k)} = \beta\Delta \mathbf{w}^{(k-1)} - \eta \nabla_{\mathbf{w}} F(\mathbf{w}^{(k-1)})^TŒîw(k)=Œ≤Œîw(k‚àí1)‚àíŒ∑‚àáw‚ÄãF(w(k‚àí1))TÔªø

      1. Adds in the scaled previous step

        w(k)‚Üêw(k‚àí1)+Œîw(k)\mathbf{w}^{(k)} ‚Üê \mathbf{w}^{(k-1)} +\Delta \mathbf{w}^{(k)}w(k)‚Üêw(k‚àí1)+Œîw(k)Ôªø

      where Œ≤<1\beta <1Œ≤<1Ôªø

      ‚áí Converges much faster

If we loop through the samples in the same order, we may get cyclic behavior

‚áí add randomness to improve convergence

  • Simultaneously adjust the function at all training points
    • Process all training points before making a single
      adjustment
    • ‚ÄúBatch‚Äù update
  • Incremental update (stochastic GD)
    • Why incremental update works?
      • Individual training instances contribute different directions to the overall gradient (final gradient points is the average of individual gradients)
      • Consider case where X1=X2=‚ãØ=XDX_1=X_2 = \dots=X_DX1‚Äã=X2‚Äã=‚ãØ=XD‚ÄãÔªø (data clotting)
    • As data get increasingly diverse, the benefits of incremental updates decrease, but do not entirely vanish.
    • When does incremental update works?

      ‚Üí The model to always minimize the error on the latest instance, hence limit the convergence

      ‚áí Shrink the learning rate with iterations ‚áí parameters swing less and less towards the new point

    • SGD converges ‚Äúalmost surely‚Äù to a global or local minimum for most functions.
      • Sufficient condition: step sizes follow the following conditions
        [Robbins and Munro, 1951]
        ‚àëkŒ∑k=‚àû\sum_k \eta_k=‚àû‚àëk‚ÄãŒ∑k‚Äã=‚àûÔªø
        • Eventually the entire parameter space can be searched ‚àëkŒ∑k2<‚àû\sum_k \eta_k^2 <\infty‚àëk‚ÄãŒ∑k2‚Äã<‚àûÔªø
        • The steps shrink!
      • The fastest converging series that satisfies both above requirements Œ∑k‚àù1k\eta_k\propto\frac{1}{k}Œ∑k‚Äã‚àùk1‚ÄãÔªø (the optimal rate of shrinking the step size for strongly convex functions, or heuristically determined)
      • If the loss is convex, SGD converges to the optimal solution; otherwise, it converges to a local minimum
  • The empirical risk is an unbiased estimate of the expected divergence:

    Loss(W)=E[div(f(X;W),g(X))]‚áíE[Loss(W)]=E[div(f(X;W),g(X))]Loss(W) = \mathbb{E} [div(f(X;W),g(X))] ‚áí \mathbb{E} [Loss(W)] = \mathbb{E} [div(f(X;W),g(X))] Loss(W)=E[div(f(X;W),g(X))]‚áíE[Loss(W)]=E[div(f(X;W),g(X))]Ôªø

    • Having very few samples makes the estimate swing wildly with the sample position
    • But SGD provides significantly quicker updates than batch ‚áí‚áí‚áíÔªø Mini-batch
  • Mini-batch update
    • Adjust the function at a small, randomly chosen subset of points.
    • Vary the subsets randomly in different passes through the training data

    Larger minibatches

    = less variance
    = few updates per epoch

    Mini-batch loss:

    MBLoss(W)=1b‚àëi=1bdiv(f(Xi;W),g(Xi))MBLoss(W) = \frac{1}{b} \sum_{i=1}^b div(f(X_i;W),g(X_i)) MBLoss(W)=b1‚Äã‚àëi=1b‚Äãdiv(f(Xi‚Äã;W),g(Xi‚Äã))Ôªø

    ‚áíE[MBLoss(W)]=E[div(f(X;W),g(X))]‚áí \mathbb{E} [MBLoss(W)] = \mathbb{E} [div(f(X;W),g(X))] ‚áíE[MBLoss(W)]=E[div(f(X;W),g(X))]Ôªø

    var[MBLoss]=1bvar[div] var[MBLoss] = \frac{1}{b}var[div]var[MBLoss]=b1‚Äãvar[div]Ôªø where b<<Nb << Nb<<NÔªø

    Nestorov‚Äôs method for mini-batch update:

    Ensures that the

Generalization

  • Batch Normalization (BN)

    ‚Üí Training assumes the training data are all similarly distributed, but this is not always the case in practice!!

    • Each minibatch may have a different distribution ‚áí ‚Äúcovariate shift‚Äù
      • The shifts can be large!
      • Can affect training badly!

      ‚áí ‚ÄúMove‚Äù all batches to a ‚Äústandard‚Äù (mean 000Ôªø and unit standard variance) location of the space and shift to appropriate spot.

    • Training‚Ä¶
      • Because of BN (divided by mean of all sample), the training instances within the mini-batch are no longer independent
      • Derivative of the loss w.r.t Œ≥\gammaŒ≥Ôªø and Œ≤\betaŒ≤Ôªø can be easily calculated, and so for every uiu_iui‚ÄãÔªø.
      • For every i=ji=ji=jÔªø pair
      • For i‚â†ji\neq jiÓÄ†=jÔªø

    To compute the derivative of minibatch loss w.r.t any ziz_izi‚ÄãÔªø, we must consider all z^j\hat{z}_jz^j‚ÄãÔªø in the batch

    • Inference
      • BN requires ŒºB\mu_BŒºB‚ÄãÔªø, œÉB2\sigma_B^2œÉB2‚ÄãÔªø for test data ‚Üê achieve this by averaging all training minibatches
        • ŒºB=1Nbatches‚àëbatchŒºB(batch)\mu_B = \frac{1}{N_{\text{batches}}} \sum_{\text{batch}} \mu_B (\text{batch})ŒºB‚Äã=Nbatches‚Äã1‚Äã‚àëbatch‚ÄãŒºB‚Äã(batch)Ôªø
        • œÉB2=B(B‚àí1)Nbatches‚àëbatchœÉB2(batch)\sigma^2_B = \frac{B}{(B-1)N_{\text{batches}}} \sum_{\text{batch}} \sigma^2_B (\text{batch})œÉB2‚Äã=(B‚àí1)Nbatches‚ÄãB‚Äã‚àëbatch‚ÄãœÉB2‚Äã(batch)Ôªø (unbiased estimator for the variance)

        where ŒºB(batch) \mu_B (\text{batch})ŒºB‚Äã(batch)Ôªø and œÉB2(batch)\sigma^2_B (\text{batch})œÉB2‚Äã(batch)Ôªø are obtained from the final converged network.

      • BN may only be applied to some layers (or even only selected neurons in the layer)
      • Improves both convergence rate and neural network performance
        • Anecdotal evidence that BN eliminates the need for dropout
        • To get maximum benefit from BN, learning rates must be increased and learning rate decay can be faster since the data generally remain in the high-gradient regions of the activations
        • Also needs better randomization of training data order.
  • Smoothing
    • Consider a binary 100-dimensional input
    • There are 2100=10302^{100} = 10^{30}2100=1030Ôªø possible inputs
    • Complete specification of the function will require specification of 103010^{30}1030Ôªø output values.
    • A training set with only 101510^{15}1015Ôªø training instances will be off by a factor of 101510^{15}1015Ôªø

    ‚áí Steep changes that enable overfitted responses are facilitated by perceptrons with large wwwÔªø.

    ‚áí Constraining the weights to be low will force slower perceptrons and smoother output response ‚áí Regularization.

    • The ‚Äúdesired‚Äù output is generally smooth - capture statistical or average trends.
    • Unconstrained model will model individual instances instead.

    Smoothness through network structure

    • For a given number of parameters deeper networks impose more smoothness than shallow ones
    • Training with more data is also better :))

    Other smoothing techniques:

    • L1L_1L1‚ÄãÔªø regularization of network activations
    • Regularizing with added noise
    • Bagging (proposed by Leo Breiman)
      • Sample training data and train several different classifiers
      • Classify test instance with entire ensemble of classifiers
      • Vote across classifiers for final decision
      • Empirically shown to improve significantly over training a single classifier from combined data

  • Dropout

    ‚Üí Training: For each input, at each iteration, ‚Äúturn off‚Äù each neuron (including inputs) with a probability 1‚àíŒ±1-\alpha1‚àíŒ±Ôªø

    • In practice, set them to 0 according to the failure of a Bernoulli random number generator with success probability Œ±\alphaŒ±Ôªø
    • Backpropagation is effectively performed only over the remaining
      network
      • The effective network is different for different inputs
      • Gradients are obtained only for the weights and biases from ‚ÄúOn‚Äù nodes to ‚ÄúOn‚Äù nodes (for the remaining, the gradient is just 0)
    • Forward pass
    • Backward pass

    ‚Üí Testing

    • For a network with a total of NNNÔªø neurons, there are 2N2^N2NÔªø possible sub-networks
      • Obtained by choosing different subsets of nodes
      • Dropout samples over all 2N2^N2NÔªø possible networks
      • Effectively learns a network that averages over all possible networks (Bagging)
    • Dropout forces the neurons to
      learn ‚Äúrich‚Äù and redundant patterns
      • E.g. without dropout, a non
        compressive layer may just ‚Äúclone‚Äù its input to its output
        • Transferring the task of learning to the rest of the network upstream
    • Dropout forces the neurons to
      learn denser patterns

    What each neuron computes?

    where DDDÔªø is a Bernoulli variable that takes a value 111Ôªø with probability Œ±\alphaŒ±Ôªø.

    • On test data, the output is the ensemble average over 2N2^N2NÔªø networks (statistical expectation of the output over all networks)

    is expected output of the iiiÔªøth neuron in the kkkÔªøth layer over all networks.

    i.e. scaling each output of each neuron by Œ±\alphaŒ±Ôªø

    • Alternatively, replace the activation by Œ±‚àí1œÉ(.)\alpha^{-1} \sigma(.) Œ±‚àí1œÉ(.)Ôªø
      • Can later use regular activation œÉ(.)\sigma(.)œÉ(.)Ôªø during testing without needs to modify the weights

    Variations

    • Zoneout (for RNNs): randomly chosen units remain unchanged across a time transition
    • Dropconnect: drop individual connections, instead of nodes
    • Shakeout: scale up the weights of randomly selected weights & fix remaining weights to a negative constant
    • Whiteout: add or multiply weight-dependent Gaussian noise to the signal on
      each connection
  • Some other tricks (heuristics)
    • Early stopping
      • Continued training can result in over fitting to training data
      • Track performance on a held-out validation set
      • Apply one of several early-stopping criterion to terminate training when performance on validation set degrades significantly

    • Gradient clipping

      ‚Üí Instability training when the DivDivDivÔªø has a steep slope

      • Set a ceiling on derivative value: if ‚àáwDiv>Œ±\nabla_{\mathcal{w}}Div > \alpha‚àáw‚ÄãDiv>Œ±Ôªø, then ‚àáwDiv‚ÜêŒ±\nabla_{\mathcal{w}}Div ‚Üê \alpha‚àáw‚ÄãDiv‚ÜêŒ±Ôªø.
    • Data augmentation

      ‚Üí Available training data will often be small

      • ‚ÄúExtend‚Äù it by distorting examples in a variety of ways to generate synthetic labelled examples
      • E.g. rotation, stretching, adding noise, etc.
    • Input normalization
CNN (L9, Sep 25 - L12, Oct 4)

Task: Find a word in a long speech/ find a pattern in an image

‚Üí regular NN requires large training data with the pattern at every position

  • Want NN to be shift-invariance (word or pattern can be anywhere in the speech/ image)
    • Scanning

    for l = 1:L      # layers operate on vector at (x,y) on the most outer loop

    Scanning without distribution

    Distributed scanning

    • (2 levels) K0DN1+K1N1N2+N2N3K_0DN_1 + K_1N_1N_2 + N_2 N_3K0‚ÄãDN1‚Äã+K1‚ÄãN1‚ÄãN2‚Äã+N2‚ÄãN3‚ÄãÔªø (ignore bias term)
      • Fewer parameters than a non-distributed net with identical number of neurons
    • (3 levels) Total parameters (ignore bias term) K0DN1+K1N1N2+K2N2N3K_0DN_1 + K_1N_1N_2 + K_2 N_2 N_3K0‚ÄãDN1‚Äã+K1‚ÄãN1‚ÄãN2‚Äã+K2‚ÄãN2‚ÄãN3‚ÄãÔªø
    • 1st layer evaluates smaller blocks of pixels
    • The next layer evaluates the windows of outputs from the first layer
    • Distribution forces hierarchical representations with localized patterns in lower layers
      • More generalizable
    • Fewer computations
      • Reusable computations from lower layers
    • Far fewer number of parameter
    # Distributed scanning with images
Y(0,:,:,:) = Image
for l = 1:L  # layers operate on vector at (x,y)
	for x = 1:W_{l-1}-K_l+1 
		for y = 1:H_{l-1}-K_l+1
			for j = 1:D_l
				z(l,j,x,y) = b(l,j)
				for i = 1:D_{l-1}
					for x‚Äô = 1:K_l
						for y‚Äô = 1:K_l
							z(l,j,x,y) += w(l,i,j,x‚Äô,y‚Äô)*Y(l-1,i,x+x‚Äô-1,y+y‚Äô-1)
				Y(l,j,x,y) = activation(z(l,j,x,y))
Y = softmax( Y(L,:,1,1)..Y(L,:,W-K+1,H-K+1) )

        # W(l): 4D D_l x D_{l-1] x K_l x K_l tensor
# The product in blue is a tensor inner product with a scalar output
Y(0) = Image
for l = 1:L  # layers operate on vector at (x,y)
	m = 1
		for x = 1:stride:W_l-1-K
			n = 1
			for y = 1:stride:H_l-K_l+1
				segment = Y(l-1,x:x+K_l-1,y:y+K_l-1)
				z(l,m,n) = W(l).segment #tensor inner prod.
				Y(l,m,n) = activation(z(l,m,n))
				n++
			m++
Y = softmax(Y(L))
      • Pooling - account for some jitter in the first-level patterns

General architecture of a convolutional neural network (CNN)

  • Study on neural correlates of vision [Hubel and Wiesel, 1959]
  • Show complex buildup ‚Äì building more complex patterns by composing early neural responses
    • Successive transformation through Simple-Complex combination layers
  • Complex C-cells build from similarly oriented simple cells
    • They ‚Äúfine-tune‚Äù the response of the simple cell
  • NeoCognitron [Kunihiko Fukushima, 1980]
    • Positional invariance of input: ‚ÄúYour grandmother cell fires even if your grandmother
      moves to a different location in your field of vision.‚Äù
    • Visual system consists of a hierarchy of modules, each comprising a layer of ‚ÄúS-cells‚Äù followed by a layer of ‚ÄúC-cells‚Äù
      • S-cells respond to the signal in the previous layer (learnable)
      • C-cells confirm the S-cells‚Äô response (fixed)
    • U0U_0U0‚ÄãÔªø is the retina
    • The deeper the layer, the larger the receptive field of each neuron
      • Cell planes get smaller with layer number
      • Number of planes increases
    • Unsupervised learning:
      • Randomly initialize S cells, perform Hebbian learning updates in response to input
        • Œîwij=ùë•iyj\Delta w_{ij} =ùë•_i y_jŒîwij‚Äã=xi‚Äãyj‚ÄãÔªø
        • Within any layer, at any position, only the maximum SSSÔªø from all the layers is
          selected for update
          • Also viewed as max-valued cell from each S column
            • Ensures only one of the planes picks up any feature
            • If multiple max selections are on the same plane, only the largest is chosen
          • But across all positions, multiple planes will be selected
          • Updates are distributed across all cells within the plane
      • Ensures different planes learn different features
        • E.g. Given many examples of the character ‚ÄúA‚Äù the different cell planes in the S-C layers may learn the patterns shown
        • Given other characters, other planes will learn their components
        • Going up the layers goes from local to global receptor fields
          • Winner-take-all strategy makes it robust to distortion
          • Unsupervised: Effectively clustering
      • The neocognitron is fully unsupervised
        • Semantic labels are automatically learned
          • Can we add external supervision?
            • Temporal correlation: Homma, Atlas, Marks, ‚Äò88
            • TDNN: Lang, Waibel et. al., 1989, ‚Äò90
            • Convolutional neural networks: LeCun
      • Add an extra decision layer after the final C layer - produces a class-label output

        = a fully feed forward MLP with shared parameters

        • All the S-cells within an S-plane have the same weights
        • Train the S-cell weights in every plane of every layer with backpropagation
        • C-cells are not updated

      Note: The original Neocognitron actually uses many identical copies of a neuron in each S and C plane = ‚Äúscanning‚Äù with a single copy

      • Assuming square receptive fields, rather than elliptical ones
      • Receptive field of S cells in lllÔªøth layer is Kl√óKlK_l \times K_lKl‚Äã√óKl‚ÄãÔªø
      • Receptive field of C cells in lllÔªøth layer is Ll√óLlL_l \times L_lLl‚Äã√óLl‚ÄãÔªø
        • C cells ‚Äústride‚Äù by more than one pixel, resulting in a shrinking, or ‚Äúdown-sampling‚Äù of the maps

  • A convolutional layer

What is a convolution?

‚Üí Scanning an image with a ‚Äúfilter‚Äù

‚Üí The ‚Äúcube‚Äù view of input maps

The computation of the convolutional map at any location sums the convolutional outputs at all planes.

  • Convolutional layers and the MLP are learnable
    • Corresponding the ‚ÄúS-planes‚Äù in the Neocognitron
    • Each convolutional layer is an affine map with an activation.
  • Pooling layers are fixed and generally not learnable

  • Engineering consideration
    • Zero-padding
      • Note that image size = N√óNN\times NN√óNÔªø, filter size = M√óMM\times MM√óMÔªø

        ‚áí output size = (N‚àíM)+1√ó(N‚àíM)+1(N-M) +1 \times (N-M) + 1(N‚àíM)+1√ó(N‚àíM)+1Ôªø ‚áí sometimes is not acceptable!

      • Zero-pad the input so that convolution has the same size as the original image
        • Odd LLLÔªø-width filter: Pad on both left and right with L‚àí12\frac{L-1}{2}2L‚àí1‚ÄãÔªø columns of zeros
        • Even LLLÔªø-width filter: Pad one side with L2\frac{L}{2}2L‚ÄãÔªø columns of zeros, and the other with L2‚àí1\frac{L}{2} -12L‚Äã‚àí1Ôªø columns of zeros
        • The resulting image is width N+L‚àí1N+L -1N+L‚àí1Ôªø
        • The result of the convolution is width NNNÔªø
    • Pooling

      ‚Üí ‚Äúscanning‚Äù the input

      • Max pooling
      • Mean pooling
      • p-norm
      • A learned NN filter
    • Downsampling

      ‚Üí An N√óNN\times NN√óNÔªø input compressed by a P√óPP\times PP√óPÔªø pooling filter with stride DDDÔªø results in an output map of size ‚åàN‚àíPD‚åâ+1√ó‚åàN‚àíPD‚åâ+1\left\lceil \frac{N-P}{D} \right\rceil + 1 \times \left\lceil \frac{N-P}{D} \right\rceil + 1 ‚åàDN‚àíP‚Äã‚åâ+1√ó‚åàDN‚àíP‚Äã‚åâ+1Ôªø

      ‚Üí Shrinking of the map

    • Upsampling
      • Introduces rows and columns for every map in the layer
        • Effectively increasing the size of the map by factor in every direction
      • Used explicitly to increase the map size by a uniform factor
      • Not useful to follow it by a pooling layer nor as the final layer of a CNN

      ‚Üí Upsampling by factor SSSÔªø is the same as striding by factor 1S\frac{1}{S}S1‚ÄãÔªø

  • End-to-end Convolutional Neural Networks
    • Preprocessing
      • 3 RGB channels
      • Scaled to smaller sizes, e.g. 128√ó128128\times 128128√ó128Ôªø or even 32√ó3232 \times 3232√ó32Ôªø - based on how much will fit on GPU
      • Typically cropped to square image
    • Input is convolved with a set of K1K_1K1‚ÄãÔªø filters
      • Typically K1K_1K1‚ÄãÔªø is a power of 222Ôªø, e.g. 2,4,8,16,32,‚Ä¶2, 4, 8, 16, 32,‚Ä¶2,4,8,16,32,‚Ä¶Ôªø
      • Better notation: Filters are typically 5√ó5(√ó3)5\times5(\times3)5√ó5(√ó3)Ôªø, 3√ó3(√ó3)3\times3(\times3)3√ó3(√ó3)Ôªø, or even 1√ó1(√ó3)1\times1(\times3)1√ó1(√ó3)Ôªø
      • Typical stride: 111Ôªø or 222Ôªø
      • Zero-padded according to the size of the chosen filter
      • Followed by a ReLU activation
      • Downsampling
    • Parameters to be learned:
      • The weights of the neurons in the final MLP
      • The (weights and biases of the) filters for every convolutional layer
    • E.g. Digit classification
  • Learning the CNN
    • Total parameters required for the convolutional layers:
    • Training CNN through GD
    • Backpropagation
      • Compute the derivatives w.r.t. the affine combination Z(l,.)Z(l,.)Z(l,.)Ôªø maps from the activation output maps Y(l,.)Y(l,.)Y(l,.)Ôªø

        where fffÔªø is the activation function.

      • For convolutional layers, compute the derivative w.r.t. Y(l‚àí1,.)Y(l-1,.)Y(l‚àí1,.)Ôªø and w(l)w(l)w(l)Ôªø given derivatives w.r.t. Z(l)Z(l)Z(l)Ôªø
        • Each Y(l‚àí1,m)Y(l-1,m)Y(l‚àí1,m)Ôªø map/channel influences Z(l,n)Z(l,n)Z(l,n)Ôªø through the mmmÔªøth ‚Äúplane‚Äù (channel) of the nnnÔªøth filter wl(m,n)w_l(m,n)wl‚Äã(m,n)Ôªø
        • Each Y(l‚àí1,m,x,y)Y(l-1,m,x,y)Y(l‚àí1,m,x,y)Ôªø affects several z(l,n,x‚Äô,y‚Äô)z(l,n,x‚Äô,y‚Äô)z(l,n,x‚Äô,y‚Äô)Ôªø terms
          • z(l,n,x‚Äô,y‚Äô)z(l,n,x‚Äô,y‚Äô) z(l,n,x‚Äô,y‚Äô)Ôªø += Y(l‚àí1,m,x,y)wl(m,n,x‚àíx‚Äô,y‚àíy‚Äô)Y(l-1,m,x,y)w_l(m,n,x-x‚Äô,y-y‚Äô)Y(l‚àí1,m,x,y)wl‚Äã(m,n,x‚àíx‚Äô,y‚àíy‚Äô)Ôªø

          = convolution of the zero-padded dDivdz(l,n,x,y)\frac{dDiv}{dz(l,n,x,y)}dz(l,n,x,y)dDiv‚ÄãÔªø maps (padded with KlK_lKl‚ÄãÔªø zeros on each side, where wlw_lwl‚ÄãÔªø is of size Dl‚àí1√óKl√óKlD_{l-1} \times K_l \times K_lDl‚àí1‚Äã√óKl‚Äã√óKl‚ÄãÔªø) by the transposed and flipped filter (same size as the YYYÔªø maps before zero-padded)

          # The weight W(l,m)is a 3D D_{l-1} x K_l x K_l
# Assuming dz has already been obtained via backprop
dzpad = zeros(D_l x(H_l + 2(K_l-1))x(W_l +2(K_l-1)) # zeropad
for j = 1:D
	 for i = 1:D # Transpose and flip
			 Wflip(i,j,:,:) = flipLeftRight(flipUpDown(W(l,i,j,:,:))) 
	 dzpad(j,K_l:K_l+H_l-1,K_l:K_l+W_l-1) = dz(l,j,:,:) # center map
 end
 for j = 1:D_{l-1}
	 for x = 1:W_{l-1}
		 for y = 1:H_{l-1}
			  segment = dzpad(:, x:x+K_l-1, y:y+K_l-1) #3D tensor
				dy(l-1,j,x,y) = Wflip.segment #tensor inner prod.
        • Each weight wl(m,n,x‚Äô,y‚Äô)w_l(m,n,x‚Äô,y‚Äô)wl‚Äã(m,n,x‚Äô,y‚Äô)Ôªø affects several z(l,n,x,y)z(l,n,x,y)z(l,n,x,y)Ôªø but only within a single affine (z(l,n,.,.)z(l,n,.,.)z(l,n,.,.)Ôªø) map/channel

          ‚Üí also is a convolution

      • For pooling layers, compute the derivative w.r.t Y(l‚àí1)Y(l-1)Y(l‚àí1)Ôªø given derivatives w.r.t. Y(l)Y(l)Y(l)Ôªø
        • Max pooling layer
        • Mean pooling layer

          For k‚àà{i,i+Klpool‚àí1},n‚àà{j,j+Klpool‚àí1}k\in\{i,i+K_{lpool} -1\}, n\in\{j,j+K_{lpool}-1\}k‚àà{i,i+Klpool‚Äã‚àí1},n‚àà{j,j+Klpool‚Äã‚àí1}Ôªø,

          = channel-wise convolution of dy(l,m)dy(l,m)dy(l,m)Ôªø by a ‚Äúuniform‚Äù filter with value 1Klpool2\frac{1}{K_{lpool}^2}Klpool2‚Äã1‚ÄãÔªø

      • Backprop through down-sampling layer
        1. Allocate a map of the size of the input that was down-sampled
        1. The ‚Äúdeleted‚Äù values (blackened) do not affect the output (derivative w.r.t. these elements is 000Ôªø)
        1. The remaining values are identical in the original and down-sampled maps in the forward pass - the divergence derivatives too will be identical
        # H and W are the height and width of the input
# to the downsampling layer in the forward pass
# S is the stride in the forward pass
# dz contains the divergence derivative for the D/S
# output z in the forward pass

function dy = backprop_through_DS(dz, S, H, W)
	#c = number of channels in dz
	dy = zeros(c,H,W)  # preallocate to right size and set to 0
	for i = 1:width(z)
		for j = 1:height(z)
			dy(:,(i-1)S+1, (j-1)S+1) = dz(:,i,j)
	return dy
      • Backprop through the up-sampling layer
        # S is the stride in the forward pass
# dz contains the divergence derivative for the U/S
# output z in the forward pass

function dy = backprop_through_Upsampling (dz, S)
	#c = number of channels in dz
	k = 0
	for i = 1:S:width(z)
		l = 0
		for j = 1:S:height(z)
			dy(:,k, l) = dz(:,i,j)
			l++
		k++
	return dy

Invariance

‚Üí Generalize shift-invariance = transform invariance

  • Shift-invariance
  • Transform invariance (TtT_t Tt‚ÄãÔªø= rotation, scaling, reflections etc.)

‚Üí Derivatives flow back through the transforms to update individual filters ‚Äì Need point
correspondences between original and transformed filters.

Common tasks
  • Finding bounding boxes

    The flatten layer outputs to two separate output layers

    • One predicts the class of the output
    • The second predicts the corners of the bounding box of the object (8 coordinates)

    The divergence minimized is the sum of the cross-entropy loss of the classifier layer and L2 loss of the bounding-box predictor

    ‚Üí Multi-task learning

  • Pose estimation
    • Use the same mechanism to predict the joints of a stick model

Well-known architectures

  • Conventional convolutions
    • Each layer of each filter scans its corresponding map to produce a convolved map
    • N input channels will require a filter with N layers
    • The independent convolutions of each layer of the filter result in N convolved maps
    • The N convolved maps are added together to produce the final output map (or channel) for that filter
  • Depth-wise convolution
    • The convolution step is performed only once
    • The simple summation is replaced by a weighted sum across channels - different weights (for summation) produce different output channels
  • Le-net 5

    Digit recognition on MNIST (32√ó3232\times3232√ó32Ôªø images)

    • Conv1: 6 5√ó55\times55√ó5Ôªø filters in first conv layer (no zero pad), stride 1 ‚áí 6 28√ó2828\times2828√ó28Ôªø maps
    • Pool1: 2√ó22\times22√ó2Ôªø max pooling, stride 2 ‚áí 6 14√ó1414\times1414√ó14Ôªø maps
    • Conv2: 16 5√ó55\times55√ó5Ôªø filters in second conv layer, stride 1, no zero pad ‚áí 16 10√ó1010\times 1010√ó10Ôªø maps
    • Pool2: 2√ó2 2\times2 2√ó2Ôªø max pooling with stride 2 for 2nd conv layer ‚áí 16 5√ó55\times55√ó5Ôªø maps (400 values in all)
    • FC: 3 MLP layers
      • 120 neurons, 84 neurons, and finally 10 output neurons

  • Training issues
    • Standard convergence issues ‚áí Adam or other momentum-style algorithms + batch normalization
    • The number of parameters can quickly become very large
    • Insufficient training data to train well ‚áí Data augmentation
      • Rotation: uniformly chosen random angle between 0¬∞ and 360¬∞
      • Translation: random translation between -10 and 10 pixels
      • Rescaling: random scaling with scale factor between 1/1.6 and 1.6 (log-uniform)
      • Flipping: yes or no (Bernoulli)
      • Shearing: random shearing with angle between -20¬∞ and 20¬∞
      • Stretching: random stretching with stretch factor between 1/1.3 and 1.3 (log-uniform)
  • What do filters learn?

    ‚Üí Receptive fields

    ‚Üí For the higher level neurons, the actual receptive field is not immediately obvious
    and must be calculated

    • What patterns in the input do the neurons actually respond to?
    • Estimate the receptive field by setting the output of the neuron to 1, and learning the input by backpropagation
  • Applications:
    • Image classification
    • Used in speech and audio processing (Convnets on spectrograms)
    • Used in text processing

RNN (L13, Oct 9 - L17, Oct 30)

Sequence of vectors ‚Üí classification result (eg: past stock data ‚Üí buy or sell)

Eg: Text analysis (identify topic, translation - English to French)

Finite-response model

NNNÔªø is width of the system (prediction consider N points of history)

( also called a Time-Delay neural network)

Problem: Increasing ‚Äúhistory‚Äù makes the network more complex (& lack of computer memory) but real system usually have long-term dependencies

‚Üí want infinite response systems

NARX network

= ‚ÄúNonlinear Autoregressive network with exogenous inputs‚Äù

‚ÄúMemory‚Äù of the past is in the output YtY_tYt‚ÄãÔªø and not in the network.

‚Üí want to ‚Äúremember‚Äù the past

Simple recurrent networks:

Jordan networks maintain a running average of outputs in a ‚Äúmemory‚Äù unit

  • Consider entire past, rather than immediate past

Elman networks store hidden unit values for one time instant in a ‚Äúcontext‚Äù unit that carry historical state

  • Only the weight from the memory unit to the hidden unit is learned
  • During training no gradient is backpropagated over the ‚Äú1‚Äù link

State-space models

hth_tht‚ÄãÔªø is the state of the network (summarizes information about the entire past)

‚Üí need to define h‚àí1h_{-1}h‚àí1‚ÄãÔªø

Training a RNN

¬†*¬†f1\text{ * } f_1¬†*¬†f1‚ÄãÔªø is usually the tanh‚Å°\tanh tanhÔªø function.

Backpropagation through time

  • Forward pass: pass the entire data sequence through the network, generate outputs
    # Assuming h(-1,*) is known
# Assuming L hidden-state layers and an output layer
# W_c(*) and W_r(*) are matrics, b(*) are vectors
# W_c are weights for inputs from current time
# W_r is recurrent weight applied to the previous time
# W_o are output layre weights

for t in range(T): # Including both ends of the index
	h(t,0) = x(t) # Vectors. Initialize h(0) to input
	for l in range(L+1): # hidden layers operate at time t
		z(t,l) = W_c(l)*h(t,l-1) + W_r(l)*h(t-1,l) + b(l)
		h(t,l) = tanh(z(t,l)) # Assuming tanh activation function
	z_o(t) = W_o*h(t,L) + b_o
Y(t) = softmax( z_o (t) )
  • Backward pass: compute gradients via backpropagation

    ‚Üí Compute ‚àáY(T)DIV(Y(0:T),X(0:T))\nabla_{Y(T)}DIV(Y(0:T),X(0:T)) ‚àáY(T)‚ÄãDIV(Y(0:T),X(0:T))Ôªø, where Div(t)Div(t)Div(t)Ôªø measure the divergence of desire output & the output by the network (usually cross-entropy loss or MSE).

    • Suppose DIV=‚àëtDiv(t)DIV = \sum_t Div(t)DIV=‚àët‚ÄãDiv(t)Ôªø

    Some calculus rules

    • Z(2)(t)Z^{(2)}(t)Z(2)(t)Ôªø is the pre-activation value of the neurons at the output layer at time t
    • Z(1)(t)Z^{(1)}(t)Z(1)(t)Ôªø is the pre-activation value of the hidden layer at time
    • Y(t)Y( t)Y(t)Ôªø is the output at time
    • h(t)h(t)h(t)Ôªø is the output of the hidden layer at time

    Gradient derivation

    # Assuming forward pass has been completed
# Jacobian(x,y) is the jacobian of x w.r.t. y
# Assuming dY(t) = gradient(div,Y(t)) available for all t
# Assuming all dz, dh, dW and db are initialized to 0

for t in range(T,0): # Backward through time
	dz_o(t) = dY(t)*Jacobian(Y(t),z_o(t))
	dW_o += h(t,L)dz_o(t)
	db_o += dz_o(t)
	dh(t,L) += dz_o(t)W_o
	for l in range(L+1,0): # Reverse through layers
		dz(t,l) = dh(t,l)Jacobian(h(t,l),z(t,l))
		dh(t,l-1) += dz(t,l)*Wc(l)
		dh(t-1,l) = dz(t,l)*Wr(l)
		dW_c(l) += h(t,l-1)*dz(t,l)
		dW_r(l) += h(t-1,l)*dz(t,l)
		db(l) += dz(t,l)

‚áí Can be generalize to any RNN architecture

Some architectures

  • One-to-one (conventional MLP)
  • One-to-many (sequence generation, image captioning)

    Decoding

    • Given image ‚Üí process it with CNN to get output of classification layer
    • Sequentially generate words by drawing from the conditional output distribution.

    Training: given several (Image, Caption) pairs ‚Äì The image network is pretrained on a large corpus, e.g. ImageNet

    • Forward pass: Produce output distributions given the image and caption
    • Backward pass: Compute the divergence w.r.t. training caption, and backpropagate derivatives
      • All components of the network, including final classification layer of the image classification net are updated
      • The CNN portions of the image classifier are not modified (transfer learning)

    # Assuming encoded input H (from text, image, video)  is available
# Now generate the output y_out(1),y_out(2),‚Ä¶
t = 0
h_out(0) = H   # Encoder embedding

# Note: begins with a ‚Äústart of sentence‚Äù symbol <sos>
y_out(0) = <sos>
do
	t = t+1
	[y(t),h_out(t)] = RNN_output_step(h_out(t-1), y_out(t-1), H)
	y_out(t) = generate(y(t)) # Beam search, random, or greedy
until y_out(t) == <eos>

  • Many-to-one (speech recognition, question & answer)
    • Output generated when last vector processed (probability distribution over phonemes)
    • Output are actually produced for every input, but we only read at the end
    • Divergence only defined at the final input (propagate through the net to update all parameters)
    • But the net can assume the previous block is not useful
      • Trick: assign last output to every input to have one-to-one correspondence
      • Compute the weighted sum of divergence instead (e.g. set all weights except last one to 0 or some small value)
  • Many-to-many (input ‚â†\neqÓÄ†=Ôªø output ‚Üí machine translation, input = output ‚Üí stock prediction)
    • Time-synchronous network (e.g. Part-of-Speech tagging)
      • 1 input ‚Üí 1 output
    • Order synchronous, time asynchronous sequence-to-sequence generation
      • E.g. speech recognition ‚Äì Exact location of output is unknown a prior
      • Solve by compare outputs to the next one and output if different

        ‚Üí Cannot distinguish between an extended symbol and repetitions of the symbol

      • Impose external constraints on what sequences are allowed
        • Only allow sequences corresponding to dictionary words
        • Using special ‚Äúseparating‚Äù symbols to separate repetitio

        ‚Üí do not guarantee optimal order-synchronous sequences

        n = 1
best(1)= argmax_i(y(1,i))
for t = 1:T
	best(t)= argmax_i(y(t,i))
	if (best(t) != best(t-1))
		 out(n) = best(t-1)
		 time(n) = t-1
		 n = n+1
      • How to train?
        • Output sequence length <= input sequence length
        • The time-stamps of the output symbols give us the ‚Äúalignment‚Äù of the
          output sequence to the input sequence - but we don‚Äôt know that given the output sequence
        • Training without alignment
          • Given unaligned KKKÔªø-length compressed symbol sequence S=S0‚Ä¶SK‚àí1S = S_0 \dots S_{K-1}S=S0‚Äã‚Ä¶SK‚àí1‚ÄãÔªø, an NNNÔªø-length input (N‚â•KN‚â• KN‚â•KÔªø) X=X0‚Ä¶XN‚àí1X = X_0 \dots X_{N-1}X=X0‚Äã‚Ä¶XN‚àí1‚ÄãÔªø and a trained RNN
          • Find the best expansion of a compressed sequence, for a given input, given a model (Connectionist Temporal Classification)
          • Guess the alignment
            • Iteratively refine an initial alignment as the model improves
              • Initialize: Assign an initial alignment ‚Äì Either randomly, based on some heuristic, or any other rationale
              • Iterate: Train the network using the current alignment ‚Äì Re-estimate the alignment for each training instance
          • Select the most likely alignments
            • Copy output values for the target symbols into the secondary reduced structure (remove all values that not belongs to the set of target symbols - get rid of unnecessary outputs)
            • Arrange the constructed table so that from top to bottom it has the exact sequence of symbols required
            • Compose a graph such that every path in the graph from source to
              sink represents a valid alignment ‚Äì maps on to the target symbol sequence (e.g. /B//IY//F//IY/)
              • Edge scores are 1
              • Node scores are the probabilities assigned to the symbols by the neural network

              ‚Üí Find the most probable path (e.g. via Viterbi algorithm)

            • Constrain that the first symbol in the decode must be the top left block
              • The last symbol must be the bottom right
              • The rest must follow a sequence that monotonically travels
                down from top left to bottom right ‚Äì i.e. symbol chosen at any time is at the same level or at the next level to the symbol at the previous time
              • This guarantees that the sequence is an expansion of the target sequence

            • Viterbi algorithm
              • Best path to any node must be an extension of the best path to one of its parent nodes
              • Notations:
                • ytS(r)y_t^{S(r)}ytS(r)‚ÄãÔªø is the probability of the target symbols assigned to the rrrÔªøth row at the tttÔªø-th time (given input X0,‚Ä¶,XTX_0, \dots, X_TX0‚Äã,‚Ä¶,XT‚ÄãÔªø)
               #N is the number of symbols in the target output
 #S(i) is the ith symbol in target output
 #T = length of input
 
 #First create output table
 For i = 1:N
	 s(1:T,i) = y(1:T, S(i))
 
 #Now run the Viterbi algorithm
 # First, at t = 1
 BP(1,1) = -1               # assign y(1,S(1)) to be 1st best parent
 Bscr(1,1) = s(1,1)         # initialize 1st best path score to node
 Bscr(1,2:N) = 0
 for t = 2:T
	 BP(t,1) = 1;
	 Bscr(t,1) = Bscr(t-1,1)*s(t,1)
	 for i = 1:min(t,N)
		  if Bscr(t-1,i) > Bscr(t-1,i-1)
				 BP(t,i) = i
		  else
				 BP(t,i) = i-1
		 Bscr(t,i) = Bscr(t-1,BP(t,i))*s(t,i)
	
 # Backtrace
 AlignedSymbol(T) = N
 for t = T downto 2
	 AlignedSymbol(t-1) = BP(t,AlignedSymbol(t))

            • Gradient from the alignment

              Gradient w.r.t the output vector YtY_tYt‚ÄãÔªø (Zeros except at the component corresponding to the target in the estimated alignment)

          • Instead of only selecting the most likely alignment, use the statistical expectation over all possible alignments
            • Use the entire distribution of alignments ‚Üí mitigate the issue of suboptimal selection of alignment
            • Need to able to compute P(st=Sr‚à£S,X)‚àùP(st=Sr,S‚à£X)P(s_t = S_r|\mathbf{S},\mathbf{X}) \propto P(s_t = S_r,\mathbf{S}|\mathbf{X})P(st‚Äã=Sr‚Äã‚à£S,X)‚àùP(st‚Äã=Sr‚Äã,S‚à£X)Ôªø

            where

            • Œ±(t,r)=‚àëq:Sq‚ààpred(Sr)Œ±(t‚àí1,q)ytSr\alpha(t,r) = \sum_{q:S_q \in pred(S_r)} \alpha(t-1, q) y_t^{S_r}Œ±(t,r)=‚àëq:Sq‚Äã‚ààpred(Sr‚Äã)‚ÄãŒ±(t‚àí1,q)ytSr‚Äã‚ÄãÔªø is the total probability of the red subgraph

              ‚Üí in practice, compute log‚Å°Œ±(t,l)=log‚Å°(Œ±(t‚àí1,l)+Œ±(t‚àí1,l‚àí1))+log‚Å°ytS(l)\log \alpha(t,l) = \log (\alpha(t-1,l) + \alpha(t-1, l-1)) + \log y_t^S(l)logŒ±(t,l)=log(Œ±(t‚àí1,l)+Œ±(t‚àí1,l‚àí1))+logytS‚Äã(l)Ôªø to prevent underflow.

              #N is the number of symbols in the target output
#S(i) is the ith symbol in target output
#y(t,i) is the output of the network for the ith symbol at time t
#T = length of input
#First create output table
for i = 1:N
	s(1:T,i) = y(1:T, S(i))
	
#The forward recursion
# First, at t = 1
alpha(1,1) = s(1,1)
alpha(1,2:N) = 0
for t = 2:T
	alpha(t,1) = alpha(t-1,1)*s(t,1)
	for i = 2:N
		alpha(t,i) = alpha(t-1,i-1) + alpha(t-1,i)
		alpha(t,i) *= s(t,i)
            • Œ≤(t,r)=1ytSrŒ≤^(t,r)=‚àëq‚ààsucc(r)Œ≤^(t+1,q)\beta(t,r) = \frac{1}{y_t^{S_r}} \hat{\beta}(t,r) = \sum_{q\in succ(r)} \hat{\beta}(t+1,q)Œ≤(t,r)=ytSr‚Äã‚Äã1‚ÄãŒ≤^‚Äã(t,r)=‚àëq‚ààsucc(r)‚ÄãŒ≤^‚Äã(t+1,q)Ôªø
              #N is the number of symbols in the target output
 #S(i) is the ith symbol in target output
 #y(t,i) is the output of the network for the ith symbol at time t
 #T = length of input
 #First create output table
 For i = 1:N
	 s(1:T,i) = y(1:T, S(i))
 #The backward recursion to compute betahat
 # First, at t = T
 betahat(T,N) = s(T,N)
 betahat(T,1:N-1) = 0
 for t = T-1 downto 1
		 betahat(t,N) = s(t,N)*betahat(t+1,N)
		 for i = N-1 downto 1
				 betahat(t,i) = s(t,i)*(betahat(t+1,i) + betahat(t+1,i+1))
 #Compute beta from betahat
 for t = T downto 1
		 for i = N downto 1
				 beta(t,i) = betahat(t,i)/s(t,i)

            • P(st=Sr‚à£S,X)=P(st=Sr,S‚à£X)‚àëS‚ÄôrP(st=S‚Äôr,S‚à£X)P(s_t = S_r|\mathbf{S},\mathbf{X}) = \frac{P(s_t = S_r,\mathbf{S}|\mathbf{X})}{\sum_{S‚Äô_r} P(s_t = S‚Äô_r,\mathbf{S}|\mathbf{X})}P(st‚Äã=Sr‚Äã‚à£S,X)=‚àëS‚Äôr‚Äã‚ÄãP(st‚Äã=S‚Äôr‚Äã,S‚à£X)P(st‚Äã=Sr‚Äã,S‚à£X)‚ÄãÔªø=Œ±(t,r)Œ≤(t,r)‚àër‚ÄôŒ±(t,r‚Äô)Œ≤(t,r‚Äô) = \frac{\alpha(t,r) \beta(t,r)}{\sum_{r‚Äô} \alpha(t,r‚Äô) \beta(t,r‚Äô)}=‚àër‚Äô‚ÄãŒ±(t,r‚Äô)Œ≤(t,r‚Äô)Œ±(t,r)Œ≤(t,r)‚ÄãÔªø =Œ≥(t,r)= \gamma(t,r)=Œ≥(t,r)Ôªø
              #N is the number of symbols in the target output
#S(i) is the ith symbol in target output
#y(t,i) is the output of the network for the ith symbol at time t
#T = length of input
#Assuming the forward are completed first
alpha = forward(y, S)   # forward probabilities computed
beta  = backward(y, S)  # backward probabilities computed
#Now compute the posteriors
for t = 1:T
		sumgamma(t) = 0
for i = 1:N
		gamma(t,i) = alpha(t,i) * beta(t,i)
		sumgamma(t) += gamma(t,i)
for i=1:N
gamma(t,i) = gamma(t,i) / sumgamma(t)

            ‚áíDiv=‚àí‚àër‚àërŒ≥(t,r)log‚Å°ytS(r)‚áí Div = - \sum_r\sum_r \gamma(t,r) \log y_t^{S(r)}‚áíDiv=‚àí‚àër‚Äã‚àër‚ÄãŒ≥(t,r)logytS(r)‚ÄãÔªø

            • Backpropagate and aggregate derivatives over minibatch and update parameters
      • Decoding problem

        Consider a decode: R RRE EEED ‚Üí Is this the compressed symbol sequence RED or REED.

        • Solution: add a ‚Äò-‚Äô to separate symbols
          • The next symbol at the end of a sequence of blanks is always a new character
          • When a symbol repeats, there must be at least one blank between the repetitions
          • E.g. RRR---EE---DDD = RED, RR-E--EED = REED
          • The first and last column are allowed to also end at initial and
            final blanks
            • Skips are permitted across a blank, but only if the symbols on
              either side are different
            • Because a blank is mandatory between repetitions of a symbol but not required between distinct symbols
          • Include the blank ‚Äò-‚Äô in the list of vocabulary during training
        • Greedy decodes are suboptimal - select most likely time synchronous
          symbol sequence
          • blank ‚Äò-‚Äô capture the steady state in the speech, and other symbol peak up during transitioning

          ‚Üí allow greedy decode to perform well

        • Actual decoding objective - find the most likely (asynchronous) symbol sequence
          • The semi-tree hypothesis
            • The semi tree of hypotheses (assuming only 3 symbols in the vocabulary)
            • Every symbol connects to every symbol other than itself ‚Äì also connects to a blank, which connects to every symbol including itself
              • The simple structure repeats recursively
              • Each node represents a unique (partial) symbol sequence!

          The ‚Äútheoretically correct‚Äù CTC decoder
          ‚Üí In practice, the graph gets exponentially large very quickly
          ‚Üí To prevent this, pruning strategies (top-K or top-p pruning) are employed to keep the graph (and computation) manageable

          ‚áí This may cause suboptimal decodes, however ‚Äì The fact that CTC scores peak at symbol terminations minimizes the damage due to pruning

          • Beam search
    • No correspondence between input & output - order asynchronous (delayed sequence-to-sequence generation)

      Problem: Each word that is output depends only on current hidden state, and not on previous outputs

      • The hidden activation at the <eos> ‚Äústores‚Äù all information about the sentence
      • The network actually produces a probability distribution over the output vocabulary: ykw=P(Ok=w‚à£Ok‚àí1,‚Ä¶,O1,I1,‚Ä¶,IN)y_k^w = P(O_k = w| O_{k-1},\dots, O_1,I_1, \dots,I_N)ykw‚Äã=P(Ok‚Äã=w‚à£Ok‚àí1‚Äã,‚Ä¶,O1‚Äã,I1‚Äã,‚Ä¶,IN‚Äã)Ôªø
      • Objective: produce the most likely output (ends in an <eos>)

        ‚Üí Greedy: select the most probable word at each time

        • Impossible to know a priori which word leads to the more promising future

        ‚Üí Randomly draw a word at each
        time according to the output probability distribution

        • Not guaranteed to give you the most likely output
        • May sometimes give you more likely outputs than greedy drawing though

        # First run the inputs through the network
# Assuming h(-1,l) is available for all layers
t = 0
do
	[h(t),..] = RNN_input_step(x(t),h(t-1),...)
until x(t) == "<eos>"
H = h(T-1)

# Now generate the output y_out(1),y_out(2),‚Ä¶
t = 0
h_out(0) = H

# Note: begins with a ‚Äústart of sentence‚Äù symbol
#       <sos> and <eos> may be identical
y_out(0) = <sos>
do
	t = t+1
	[y(t),h_out(t)] = RNN_output_step(h_out(t-1), y_out(t-1))
	y_out(t) = argmax_i(y(t,i)) # sample(y(t)): if randomly sample from the output distribution.
until y_out(t) == <eos>
      • Problem: making a poor choice at any time commits us to a poor future
        • But we cannot know at that time the choice was poor
        • Solution: Retain only top K choices and fork the network to prevent it growing exponentially
        • Terminate path once output an <eos> ‚áí paths maybe different lengths
        ### Beam search
# Assuming encoder output H is available
path = <sos>
beam = {path}
pathscore = [path] = 1
state[path] = h[0]  # Output of encoder
do  # Step forward
	nextbeam = {}
	nextpathscore = []
	nextstate = {}
	for path in beam:
		cfin = path[end]
		hpath = state[path]
		[y,h] = RNN_output_step(hpath,cfin)
		for c in Symbolset
			newpath = path + c
			nextstate[newpath] = h
			nextpathscore[newpath] = pathscore[path]*y[c]
			nextbeam += newpath # Set addition
		end
	end
	beam, pathscore, state, bestpath = prune(nextstate,nextpathscore,nextbeam,bw)
until bestpath[end] = <eos>

### Pruning
# Note, there are smarter ways to implement this
function prune (state, score, beam, beamwidth)
	sortedscore = sort(score)
	threshold = sortedscore[beamwidth]
	prunedstate = {}
	prunedscore = []
	prunedbeam = {}
	bestscore = -inf
	bestpath = none
	for path in beam:
		if score[path] > threshold:
			prunedbeam += path # set addition
			prunedstate[path] = state[path]
			prunedscore[path] = score[path]
			if score[path] > bestscore
				bestscore = score[path]
				bestpath = path
			end
		end
	end
	return prunedbeam, prunedscore, prunedstate, bestpath
      • Training the networks
        • Forward pass:
          • Input the source and target sequences, sequentially (or by trick: input in reverse order)
          • Output a probability distribution over target symbol set (vocabulary)
        • Backward pass:
          • Compute the divergence
            between the output distribution and target word
            sequence
          • Backpropagate the derivatives of the divergence through the
            network to learn the net

          ‚Üí Randomly select a single output y(t) and corresponding desired output d(t) for backprop

  • Multiple recurrent layer RNN
  • Bidirectional RNN - analyze data both ways (start ‚Üí end, end ‚Üí start) to make predictions (backprop follow the chain of recursion separately in the forward and reverse nets)
    # Subscript f represents forward net, b is backward net
# Assuming hf (-1,*) and hb (inf,*) are known
# x(t) is the input to the block (which could be from a lower layer)#forward recurrence

for t = 0:T-1 # Going forward in time hf
	(t,0) = x(t) # Vectors. Initialize hf(0) to input
	for l = 1:Lf
	# Lf is depth of forward network hidden layerszf
		(t,l) = Wfc(l)hf(t,l-1) + Wfr(l)hf(t-1,l) + bf(l)
		hf(t,l) = tanh(zf(t,l)) # Assuming tanh activ.
		#backward recurrence
		hb(T,:,:) = hb(inf,:,:) # Just the initial value

for t = T-1:downto:0 # Going backward in time
	hb(t,0) = x(t) # Vectors. Initialize hb(0) to input
	for l = 1:Lb
	# Lb is depth of backward network hidden layers
		zb(t,l) = Wbc(l)hb(t,l-1) + Wbr(l)hb(t+1,l) + bb(l)
		hb(t,l) = tanh(zb(t,l)) # Assuming tanh activ.

for t = 0:T-1 # The output combines forward and backward
	h(t) = [hf(t,Lf); hb(t,Lb)]
    # Inputs:
# L : Number of hidden layers
# Wc, Wr, b: current weights, recurrent weights, biases# hinit: initial value of h(representing h(-1,*))
# x: input vector sequence
# T: Length of input vector sequence
# Output:
# h, z: sequence of pre-and post activation hidden
# representations from all layers of the RNN
function RNN_forward(L, Wc, Wr, b, hinit, x, T)
	h(-1,:) = hinit # hinit is the initial value for all layersfor t = 0:T-1 # Going forward in time
	h(t,0) = x(t) # Vectors. Initialize h(0) to inputfor l = 1:L
	z(t,l) = Wc(l)h(t,l-1) + Wr(l)h(t-1,l) + b(l)
	h(t,l) = tanh(z(t,l)) # Assuming tanh activ.return h
    # Subscript f represents forward net, b is backward net
# Assuming hf(-1,*) and hb(inf,*) are known
# forward pass
hf = RNN_forward(Lf, Wfc, Wfr, bf, hf(-1,:), x, T)

#backward pass
xrev = fliplr(x) # Flip it in time
hbrev = RNN_forward(Lb, Wbc, Wbr, bb, hb(inf,:), xrev, T)
hb= fliplr(hbrev) # Flip back to straighten time

#combine the two for the output
for t = 0:T-1 # The output combines forward and backward
h(t) = [hf(t,Lf); hb(t,Lb)]

    Backpropagation

    • For forward net ‚Äì Backpropagate ‚àáhf(t)Div\nabla_{h_f(t)} Div‚àáhf‚Äã(t)‚ÄãDivÔªø from ùë°=ùëáùë° = ùëát=TÔªø down to ùë°=0ùë° = 0t=0Ôªø in the usual way
      • Will obtain derivatives for all the parameters of the forward net
      • Will also get ‚àáX(t)Divforward‚àí\nabla_{X(t)} Div_{forward} -‚àáX(t)‚ÄãDivforward‚Äã‚àíÔªø Partial derivative of the gradient for ùëã(ùë°)ùëã(ùë°)X(t)Ôªø computed through the forward net
    • For backward net - Backpropagate ‚àáhb(t)Div\nabla_{h_b(t)} Div‚àáhb‚Äã(t)‚ÄãDivÔªø forward from t=0t=0t=0Ôªø up to t=Tt=T t=TÔªø
      • Will obtain derivatives for all the parameters of the forward net
      • Will also get ‚àáX(t)Divbackward‚àí\nabla_{X(t)} Div_{backward} -‚àáX(t)‚ÄãDivbackward‚Äã‚àíÔªø Partial derivative of the gradient for ùëã(ùë°) computed through the backward net
    • ‚àáX(t)Div=‚àáX(t)Divforward+‚àáX(t)Divbackward\nabla_{X(t)} Div = \nabla_{X(t)} Div_{forward} + \nabla_{X(t)} Div_{backward} ‚àáX(t)‚ÄãDiv=‚àáX(t)‚ÄãDivforward‚Äã+‚àáX(t)‚ÄãDivbackward‚ÄãÔªø
    # Inputs:
# (In addition to inputs used by L : Number of hidden layers
# dhtop: derivatives ddiv/dh*(t,L) at each time (* may be f or b)# h, z: h and z values returned by the forward pass
# T: Length of input vector sequence

# Output:
# dWc, dWb, db dhinit: derivatives w.r.t current and recurrent weights,# biases, and initial h.
# Assuming all dz, dh, dWc, dWr and db are initialized to 0

function RNN_bptt(L, Wc, Wr, b, hinit, x, T, dhtop, h, z)
	dh = zeros
	for t = T-1:downto:0 # Backward through time
		dh(t,L) += dhtop(t)
		h(t,0) = x(t)
		for l = L:1 # Reverse through layers
			dz(t,l) = dh(t,l)Jacobian(h(t,l),z(t,l))
			dh(t,l-1) += dz(t,l) Wc(l)
			dh(t-1,l) += dz(t,l) Wr(l)
			dWc(l) += h(t,l-1)dz(t,l)
			dWr(l) += h(t-1,l)dz(t,l)
			db(l) += dz(t,l)
			dx(t)= dh(t,0)
	return dx, dWc, dWr, db, dh(-1) # dh(-1) is actually dh(-1,1:L,:)
    # Subscript f represents forward net, b is backward net
# Given dh(t), t=0‚Ä¶T-1 : The sequence of gradients from the upper layer
# Also assumed available:
# x(t), t=0‚Ä¶T-1 : the input to the BRNN block
# zf(t), hf(t) : Complete forward-computation outputs for all layers of the forward net
# zb(t), hb(t) : Complete backward-computation outputs for all layers of the backward net
# Lfand Lb are the number of components in hf(t) and hb(t)

for t = 0:T-1 # Separate out forward and backward net gradients
	dhf(t) = dh(t,1:Lf)
	dhb(t) = dh(t,Lf+1:Lf+Lb)

#forward net
[dxf,dWfc,dWfr,dbf,dhf(-1)] = RNN_bptt(L, Wfc, Wfr, bf, hf(-1), x, T, dhf, hf, zf)

#backward net
xrev = fliplr(x) # Flip it in time
dhbrev = fliplr(dhb)
hbrev = fliplr(hb)
zbrev = fliplr(zb)
[dxbrev, dWbc,dWbr,dbb,dhb(inf)] = RNN_bptt(L, Wbc, Wbr, bb, hb(inf), xrev, T, dhbrev, hbrev, zbrev)
dxb= fliplr(dxbrev)

for t = 0:T-1 # Add the partials
	dx(t) = dxf(t) + dxb(t)

  • LSTM
    • Forward rule
    • Backward rule: backpropagate through an LSTM cell
    • ctc_tct‚ÄãÔªø is the linear history carried by the constant-error carousel
    • ‚ÄúForget‚Äù gate (ftf_tft‚ÄãÔªø) determines whether to carry over the history or to forget it.
    • Do suffer from exploding gradient issue
    # Input:
# C : previous value of CEC
# h : previous hidden state value (‚Äúoutput‚Äù of cell)
# x:  Current input
# [W,b]: The set of all model parameters for the cell
# These include all weights and biases
# Output:
# C : Next value of CEC
# h : Next value of h
# In the function:  sigmoid(x) = 1/(1+exp(-x))
#								   performed component-wise
# Static local variables to the cell 

static local zf, zi, zc, zo, f, i, o, Ci
function [C,h] = LSTM_cell.forward(C,h,x,[W,b])
	 zf = Wfc C+ Wfh h+ Wfx x + bf
	 f = sigmoid(zf) # forget gate
	 zi = Wic C+ Wih h+ Wix x + bi
	 i= sigmoid(zi) # input gate
	 zc = Wcc C+ Wch h+ Wcx x + bc
	 Ci = tanh(zc)  # Detecting input pattern
	 Co = f‚àòC + i‚àòCi # ‚Äú‚àò‚Äù is component-wise multiply
	 zo = Woc Co + Woh h+ Wox x + bo
	 o = sigmoid(zo) # output gate
	 ho = o ‚àò tanh(Co) # ‚Äú‚àò‚Äù is component-wise multiply
	 return Co,ho
    # Assuming h(-1,*) is known and C(-1,*)=0
# Assuming L hidden-state layers and an output layer
# Note: LSTM_cell is an indexed class with functions
# [W{l},b{l}] are the entire set of weights and biases
# for the lWo and both hidden layer are output layer weights and biases

for t = 0:T-1  # Including both ends of the index
	h(t,0) = x(t) # Vectors. Initialize h(0) to input
	for l = 1:L  # hidden layers operate at time t
		[C(t,l),h(t,l)] = LSTM_cell(t,l).forward(C(t-1,l),h(t-1,l),h(t,l-1)[W{l},b{l}])
	zo(t) = Wo h(t,L) + b
	Y(t) = softmax(zo(t))
    # Static local variables carried over from forward
 static local = zf, zi, zc, zo, f, i, o, Ci
 function [dC,dh,dx,d[W, b]] = LSTM_cell.backward(dCo, dho, C, h, Co, ho, x, [W,b])
	 # First invert ho = o‚àòtanh(C)
	 do = dho‚àò tanh(Co)T
	 d tanhCo = dho ‚àò o
	 dCo += dtanhCo ‚àò (1-tanh2(Co))T #(1-tanh2) is the derivative of tanh
	 
	 # Next invert o = sigmoid(zo)
	 dzo = do ‚àò sigmoid(zo)T ‚àò (1-sigmoid(zo))T # do x derivative of sigmoid(zo)
	 
	 # Next invert zo = WocCo + Wohh+ Woxx + bo
	 dCo+= dzo Woc #  Note ‚Äì this is a regular matrix multiply
	 dh = dzo Woh
	 dx = dzo Wox
	 dWoc = Co dzo # Note ‚Äìthis multiplies a column vector by a row vector
	 dWoh = h dzo
	 dWox = x dzo
	 dbo = dzo
	 
	 # Next invert Co = f‚àòC + i‚àòCi
	 dC= dCo ‚àò f
	 dCi = dCo ‚àò i
	 di = dCo ‚àò Ci
	 df= dCo ‚àò C
	 
	 # Next invert f = sigmoid(zf)
	 dzf = df sigmoid(zf)T (1-sigmoid(zf))T
	 # Finally invert zf = WfcC+ Wfhh + Wfxx + bf
	 dC+= dzf Wfc
	 dh += dzf Wfh
	 dx += dzf Wfx
	 dWfc = C dzf
	 dWfh = h dzf
	 dWfx = x dzf
	 dbf = dzf
	 return dC, dh, dx, d[W, b]
	 # d[W,b]is shorthand for the complete set of weight and bias derivatives
     # Assuming h(-1,*) is known and C(-1,*)=0
 # Assuming L hidden-state layers and an output layer
 # Note: LSTM_cell is an indexed class with functions
 # [W{l},b{l}] are the entire set of weights and biases
 # Wo for the lth and bo hidden layer are output layer weights and biases
 # Y is the output of the network
 # Assuming dWo and dbo and d[W{l} b{l}] (for all l) are all initialized to 0 at the start of the computation
 
 for t = T-1:0  # Including both ends of the index
	 dzo = dY(t) Softmax_Jacobian(zo(t))
	 dWo += h(t,L) dzo
	 dh(t,L) = dzo(t) Wo
	 dbo += dzo(t)
	 for l = L-1:0
		 [dC(t,l),dh(t,l),dx(t,l),d[W, b]] = LSTM_cell(t,l).backward(‚Ä¶
																				 ‚Ä¶ dC(t+1,l), dh(t+1,l)+dx(t,l+1), C(t-1,l), h(t-1,l),
																				 ‚Ä¶ C(t,l), h(t,l), h(t,l-1), [W(l),b(l)])
		 d[W{l} b{l}] += d[W,b]
  • Gated-RNN - simplify LSTM

Stability Analysis

  • Binary addition task: Add two N-bit numbers to produce a N+1-bit number
    • Input is binary

    MLP

    • Will require large number of training instances
      • Output must be specified for every pair of inputs
      • Weights that generalize will make errors ‚Äì Network trained for N-bit numbers will not work for N+1 bit numbers

    RNN

    • Can add two numbers
      of any size
    • Needs very little training data

  • Time-delay structures have bounded output if ‚Äì the function has bounded output for bounded input
    • Guaranteed if output and hidden activations are bounded
      • But will it saturate
    • What if the activation function is linear?

      where Hk(1t)H_k(1_t)Hk‚Äã(1t‚Äã)Ôªø is the hidden response at time tttÔªø with 000Ôªø initial condition (can do similar thing for vector system).

      ‚Üí It is sufficient to analyze hidden response at time t=0t=0t=0Ôªø (if the system blows up at t=0t=0t=0Ôªø, it will blows up at t=1t=1t=1Ôªø)

      • Suppose h‚àí1=0h_{-1} =0h‚àí1‚Äã=0Ôªø, we have h0(t)=WhtWxx0h_0 (t) = W_h^t W_x x_0h0‚Äã(t)=Wht‚ÄãWx‚Äãx0‚ÄãÔªø
        • Write W=UŒõU‚àí1‚áíWui=ŒªiuiW = U\Lambda U^{-1} ‚áí W u_i = \lambda_i u_iW=UŒõU‚àí1‚áíWui‚Äã=Œªi‚Äãui‚ÄãÔªø
        • For any x‚Äô=a1u1+‚ãØ+anunx‚Äô = a_1 u_1 + \dots + a_n u_nx‚Äô=a1‚Äãu1‚Äã+‚ãØ+an‚Äãun‚ÄãÔªø

          ‚áíWtx‚Äô=a1Œª1tu1+‚ãØ+anŒªntun‚áí W^t x‚Äô = a_1 \lambda^t_1 u_1 + \dots + a_n \lambda^t_n u_n‚áíWtx‚Äô=a1‚ÄãŒª1t‚Äãu1‚Äã+‚ãØ+an‚ÄãŒªnt‚Äãun‚ÄãÔªø

      • Long-term behavior depends entirely on the eigenvalues of the recurrent weights matrix
        • If the largest eigen-value is greater than 1, the system will ‚Äúblow up‚Äù
        • If it is lesser than 1, the response will ‚Äúvanish‚Äù very quickly ‚Äì Complex eigenvalues cause oscillatory response but with the same overall trends
        • Magnitudes greater than 1 will cause the system to blow up
    • Non-linear activation function analysis

    E.g. seeing a ‚Äúclose bracket‚Äù cannot affect RNN‚Äôs ability to predict an ‚Äúopen bracket‚Äù if it happened too long ago in the input

    Activations

    • Sigmoid activations saturate and the network becomes unable to retain new information
    • RELU activations blow up or vanish rapidly
    • Tanh activations are the slightly more effective at storing memory
      ‚Üí But still, for not very long
Problem with training deep networks
  • MLP = nested function: Y=fN(WNfN‚àí1(WN‚àí1fN‚àí2(‚Ä¶W1X))))Y= f_N(W_N f_{N-1}(W_{N-1} f_{N-2}(‚Ä¶W_1 X))))Y=fN‚Äã(WN‚ÄãfN‚àí1‚Äã(WN‚àí1‚ÄãfN‚àí2‚Äã(‚Ä¶W1‚ÄãX))))Ôªø
