    ‚áí‚àáfkDiv=‚àáD‚àáfN.WN‚àáfN‚àí1‚Ä¶‚àáfk+1Wk+1‚áí \nabla_{f_k} Div = \nabla D \nabla f_N . W_N \nabla f_{N-1} \dots \nabla f_{k+1} W_{k+1}‚áí‚àáfk‚Äã‚ÄãDiv=‚àáD‚àáfN‚Äã.WN‚Äã‚àáfN‚àí1‚Äã‚Ä¶‚àáfk+1‚ÄãWk+1‚ÄãÔªø

  • For an RNN, hi(1)(t)=f1(zi(1)(t)h_i^{(1)} (t) = f_1(z_i^{(1)} (t)hi(1)‚Äã(t)=f1‚Äã(zi(1)‚Äã(t)Ôªø
    • ‚àáft(zi)=[ft,1‚Ä≤(z1)0‚Ä¶00ft,2‚Ä≤(z2)‚Ä¶0‚ãÆ‚ãÆ‚ã±‚ãÆ00‚Ä¶ft,N‚Ä≤(zN)]\nabla f_t (z_i) = \begin{bmatrix} f'_{t,1}(z_1) & 0 & \dots & 0\\ 0 &f'_{t,2}(z_2) & \dots & 0\\ \vdots & \vdots & \ddots & \vdots\\ 0 & 0 & \dots & f'_{t,N}(z_N) \end{bmatrix}‚àáft‚Äã(zi‚Äã)=‚Äãft,1‚Ä≤‚Äã(z1‚Äã)0‚ãÆ0‚Äã0ft,2‚Ä≤‚Äã(z2‚Äã)‚ãÆ0‚Äã‚Ä¶‚Ä¶‚ã±‚Ä¶‚Äã00‚ãÆft,N‚Ä≤‚Äã(zN‚Äã)‚Äã‚ÄãÔªø
    • As we go back in layers, the Jacobians of the
      activations constantly shrink the derivative

      ‚Üí After a few layers the derivative of the divergence at any time is totally ‚Äúforgotten.

      ‚Üí WN,‚Ä¶,Wk+1W_N, \dots, W_{k+1}WN‚Äã,‚Ä¶,Wk+1‚ÄãÔªø are identical for RNN

  • Repeated multiplication by the weights matrix will result in exploding or vanishing gradients.
    • Resulting in insignificant or unstable gradient descent updates - get worse as depth increases
    • The relation between X(0)X(0)X(0)Ôªø and Y(T)Y(T)Y(T)Ôªø is one of a very deep network ‚Äì Gradients from errors at t=Tt=Tt=TÔªø will vanish by the time they‚Äôre propagated to t=0t=0t=0Ôªø.
  • Can we replace ‚àáfi.Wi \nabla f_i . W_i‚àáfi‚Äã.Wi‚ÄãÔªø with something that will not blow up or fade?
    • Retain memories until a switch based on the input flags them as ok to forget
    • Or remember less
  • The constant error carousel

Language models (LMs)
  • LMs model the probability distribution of token sequences in the language
  • Can be used to
    • Compute the probability of a given token sequence
    • Generate sequences from the distribution of the language

Problem: Given a sequence of words (or characters), predict the next one

  • Represent words
    • Pre-specify a vocabulary of N words in fixed (e.g. lexical) order

    ‚Üí represent each word by an NNNÔªø-dimensional vector (one-hot representation)

    • No assumption about relative importance and relationships between words

    ‚Üí If properly learned, the distances between projected points will capture semantic relations between the word.

    • uses only NNNÔªø corners of 2N2^N2NÔªø corners of a unit cube
    • (1,œµ,Œ¥)(1,\epsilon, \delta)(1,œµ,Œ¥)Ôªø has no meaning except for œµ=Œ¥=0\epsilon = \delta = 0œµ=Œ¥=0Ôªø
    • Density of points =O(NrN)= \mathcal{O}\left(\frac{N}{r^N}\right)=O(rNN‚Äã)Ôªø

    ‚áí very inefficient use of dimensions

    • Project to an MMMÔªø-dimensional subspace (M<<NM<<NM<<NÔªø) W‚ÜíPW\mathbf{W} ‚Üí \mathbf{PW}W‚ÜíPWÔªø

      Density of points =O(NrM) = \mathcal{O}\left(\frac{N}{r^M}\right)=O(rMN‚Äã)Ôªø

  • Predicting words
    • Wn=f(W0,‚Ä¶,Wn‚àí1)W_n = f(W_0, \dots, W_{n-1})Wn‚Äã=f(W0‚Äã,‚Ä¶,Wn‚àí1‚Äã)Ôªø

    ‚Üí Dimensionality problem: all inputs W0,‚Ä¶,Wn‚àí1W_0, \dots, W_{n-1}W0‚Äã,‚Ä¶,Wn‚àí1‚ÄãÔªø are high-dimensional and sparse

    • The TDNN model:
      • Predict each word based on the past NNNÔªø words ‚Äì Hidden layer has tanh()tanh()tanh()Ôªø activation, output is softmax.
      • Also learn low-dimensional
        representations of words
    • Soft bag of words: Predict word based on words in immediate context ‚Äì Without considering specific position
    • Skip-grams: Predict adjacent words based on current word
  • Generating language: Synthesis
    • Feed the drawn word as the next word in the series ‚Äì And draw the next word from the output probability distribution
    • Continue this process until we terminate generation

    <sos>: start of a sentence

    <eos>: end of a sentence

Transformer (L18, Nov 1 - L19, Nov 3)
  • Sequence ‚Üí sequence (no time synchrony)
    • Question ‚Üí response
    • Translate English ‚Üí Spanish

    ‚Üí Delayed sequence ‚Üí sequence

    • Each word that is output depends only on current hidden state, and not on previous outputs
    • Input sequence feeds into a recurrent structure, terminated by an explicit <eos> symbol

  • Issues
    • Not sufficient to have the encoder hidden state to only the initial state of the decoder
    • Misses the direct relation of the outputs to the input
  • Simple solution
    • Compute the average of all encoder hidden states
      • But the average applies the same weight to every input

Attention Models

Use a different weighted average for each output word

  • ct=1N‚àëiNwi(t)hic_t = \frac{1}{N} \sum_{i}^N w_i(t) h_ict‚Äã=N1‚Äã‚àëiN‚Äãwi‚Äã(t)hi‚ÄãÔªø

  • The attention weights wi(t)w_i(t)wi‚Äã(t)Ôªø are dynamically computed as functions of decoder state wi(t)=a(hi,st‚àí1)w_i(t) = a(h_i,s_{t-1})wi‚Äã(t)=a(hi‚Äã,st‚àí1‚Äã)Ôªø
    • Expectation: if the model is well-trained, this will automatically ‚Äúhighlight‚Äù the correct input.
    • It captures the relative importance of each position in the input to the current output
    • Weights wi(t)w_i(t)wi‚Äã(t)Ôªø must be positive and sum to 111Ôªø
      • be a distribution
      • they must be high for the most relevant inputs for the i-th output and low elsewhere
      • Two step weight computation
        • ei(t)=g(hi,st‚àí1)e_i(t) = g(h_i,s_{t-1})ei‚Äã(t)=g(hi‚Äã,st‚àí1‚Äã)Ôªø

        where options for g(.)g(.)g(.)Ôªø are

        • g(hi,st‚àí1)=huTst‚àí1g(h_i,s_{t-1}) = h_u^T s_{t-1}g(hi‚Äã,st‚àí1‚Äã)=huT‚Äãst‚àí1‚ÄãÔªø
        • g(hi,st‚àí1)=hiTWgst‚àí1g(h_i,s_{t-1}) = h^T_i W_g s_{t-1}g(hi‚Äã,st‚àí1‚Äã)=hiT‚ÄãWg‚Äãst‚àí1‚ÄãÔªø
        • g(hi,st‚àí1)=vgTtanh‚Å°(Wg[hist‚àí1])g(h_i,s_{t-1}) = v_g^T \tanh\left(W_g \begin{bmatrix}h_i\\ s_{t-1}\end{bmatrix}\right)g(hi‚Äã,st‚àí1‚Äã)=vgT‚Äãtanh(Wg‚Äã[hi‚Äãst‚àí1‚Äã‚Äã])Ôªø
        • g(hi,st‚àí1)MLP([hist‚àí1]g(h_i,s_{t-1}) MLP(\begin{bmatrix} h_i & s_{t-1}\end{bmatrix}g(hi‚Äã,st‚àí1‚Äã)MLP([hi‚Äã‚Äãst‚àí1‚Äã‚Äã]Ôªø

        • wi(t)=exp‚Å°(ei(t))‚àëjexp‚Å°(ej(t))w_i(t) = \frac{\exp(e_i(t))}{\sum_j \exp (e_j(t))}wi‚Äã(t)=‚àëj‚Äãexp(ej‚Äã(t))exp(ei‚Äã(t))‚ÄãÔªø

    Plot of wi(t)w_i(t)wi‚Äã(t)Ôªø

    • input ‚Üî output (general trend is somewhat linear because word order is roughly similar in both languages)
    • Color shows value (white
      is larger)
  • Attention-based decoding: feed ct=1N‚àëiNwi(t)hic_t = \frac{1}{N} \sum_{i}^N w_i(t) h_ict‚Äã=N1‚Äã‚àëiN‚Äãwi‚Äã(t)hi‚ÄãÔªø to decoding RNN (together with sts_tst‚ÄãÔªø) until <eos> is drawn

Query-Key-Value

Special case:

  • ki=vi=hik_i=v_i =h_iki‚Äã=vi‚Äã=hi‚ÄãÔªø
  • qt=st‚àí1q_t = s_{t-1}qt‚Äã=st‚àí1‚ÄãÔªø
  • Encoder outputs ‚Äúkey‚Äù (importance of the input at that time) and ‚Äúvalue‚Äù for a given output
  • Decoder outputs an ‚Äúquery‚Äù (evaluate which inputs to pay attention to) at each output time

Pseudocode
# Assuming encoded input 
#   (K,V) = [k_enc[0] ... k_enc[T]], [v_enc[0] ... v_enc [T]] 
# is available
t = -1  # Initial Decoder hidden state
h_out[-1] = 0 # Initial query
q[0] = 0      

# Note: begins with a ‚Äústart of sentence‚Äù symbol
#       <sos> and <eos> may be identical
Y_out[0] = <sos>
do
	t = t+1
	C = compute_context_with_attention(q[t], K, V)
	y[t], h_out[t], q[t+1] = RNN_decode_step(h_out[t-1], y_out[t-1], C)
	y[t] = generate(y[t]) # Random, or greedy
until y_out[t] == <eos>
# Takes in previous state, encoder states, outputs attention-weighted context
function compute_context_with_attention(q, K, V)
	# First compute attention
	e = []
	for t = 1:T  # Length of input
		e[t] = raw_attention(q, K[t])
	end
	maxe = max(e) # subtract max(e) from everything to prevent underflow
	a[1..T] = exp(e[1..T] - maxe)   # Component-wise exponentiation
	suma = sum(a)  # Add all elements of a
	a[1..T] = a[1..T]/suma
	
	C = 0    
	for t = 1..T
		C += a[t] * V[t]
	end
	
	return C

Training Paradigm

  • Forward pass
  • Backward pass
    • Compute a divergence between target
      output and output distributions
    • In the early stages of training, output will be random.
    • Solution:
      • ‚ÄúTeacher forcing‚Äù: passing in ground truth

        ‚áí This is cheating!!!

        ‚áí Problem: Decoder does not see
        ground truth labels during inference

      • Sampling the output to be input for some of the time
      • The ‚ÄúGumbel noise‚Äù trick: ‚Äì Sampling is not differentiable, and gradients cannot be passed through it‚Äì The ‚ÄúGumbel noise‚Äù approach recasts sampling as computing the argmax of a
        Gumbel distribution, with the network output as parameters‚Äì The ‚Äúargmax‚Äù can be replaced by a ‚Äúsoftmax‚Äù, making the process
        differentiable w.r.t. network outputs

Extensions

  • Bidirectional processing of input sequence [Neural Machine Translation by Jointly Learning to Align and Translate, Bahdanau et al. 2016]
  • Local attention vs global attention [Effective Approaches to Attention-based Neural Machine Translation, Luong et al., 2015]
  • Multihead attention
    • Have multiple query/key/value sets
      • Each attention ‚Äúhead‚Äù uses one of these set
      • The combined contexts from all heads are passed to the decoder
    • Each ‚Äúattender‚Äù focuses on a different aspect of the input that‚Äôs important for the decode

Self-attention

Compute query-key-value sets for every word

  • Using the query for that word, compute attention weights for all words
    using their keys
  • Compute updated representation for the word as attention-weighted
    sum of values of all words

‚Üí this is a ‚Äúsingle-head‚Äù self-attention block

‚Üí ‚ÄúMULTI-HEAD ATTENTION‚Äù (actually Multi-head self attention)

‚Üí Multi-head self-attention block

‚áí No need for recurrence!

!!! Didn‚Äôt take distance between tokens into consideration !!!

Positional Encoding

‚Üí Add a ‚Äúpositional‚Äù encoding to word embeddings to capture the relative distance from one another

where posposposÔªø = index of token in the input sentence, iiiÔªø = i-th dimension out of dmodeld_{model}dmodel‚ÄãÔªø.

A sequence of vectors P0,‚Ä¶,PNP_0,\dots, P_NP0‚Äã,‚Ä¶,PN‚ÄãÔªø to encode position

  • Every vector is unique (and uniquely represents time)
  • Relationship between PtP_{t}Pt‚ÄãÔªø and Pt+œÑP_{t+\tau}Pt+œÑ‚ÄãÔªø
    only depends on the distance between them ‚Üí enables the net to learn shift
    invariant ‚Äúgap‚Äù dependent relationship
    • never repeats
    • has the linearity property required
    • bounded

‚áí MœÑM_{\tau}MœÑ‚ÄãÔªø should be unitary & norm preserving

‚Üí unique encoding across dimensions

Transformer

  • ‚ÄúMasked‚Äù self-attention: forcing attention
    weights for embeddings at time
    t+1t+1t+1Ôªø and later to be 000Ôªø.

A sequence-to-sequence model that replaces recurrence with positional encoding and multi-head self attention

Tremendous decrease in model computation for similar performance as state-of-art translation models

BUT!!!

  • Often require more parameters than LSTMs at equal performance
  • Tricky on small hardware (phones, IoT, etc.)
BERT (Bidirectional Encoder Representations)
  • Learn an effective representation that can be applied to a variety of downstream tasks?
    • Word2vec (2013)
    • GloVe (2014)
  • BERT Pre-Training Corpus:
    • English Wikipedia - 2,500 million words
    • Book Corpus - 800 million word
  • BERT Pre-Training Results:
    • BERT-Base ‚Äì 110M Params
    • BERT-Large ‚Äì 340M Params
  • BERT Pre-Training Tasks:
    • MLM (Masked Language Modeling)
    • NSP (Next Sentence Prediction)
  • BERT Fine-Tuning:
    • Simply add a task-specific module after the last encoder layer to map it to the desired dimension.
    • Classification Tasks:
      • Add a feed-forward layer on top of the encoder output for the [CLS] token
    • Question Answering Tasks:
      • Train two extra vectors to mark the beginning and end of answer from paragraph
  • BERT Evaluation:
    • General Language Understanding Evaluation (GLUE)
      • Sentence pair tasks
      • Single sentence classification
    • Stanford Question Answering Dataset (SQuAD)
  • Only uses encoder of transformer to derive word and sentence embeddings
  • Trained to ‚Äúfill in the blanks‚Äù
  • A form of representation learning

Pre-training tasks can be invented flexibly‚Ä¶

  • Effective representations can be derived from a flexible regime of pre-training tasks.
  • Different NLP tasks seem to be highly transferable with each other...
  • As long as we have effective representations, that seems to form a general model which can serve as the backbone for many specialized models.
  • And scaling works!!!
    • 340M is considered large in 2018

GPT (Generative Pretrained Transformer)
  • GPT Pre-Training Corpus:
    • Similarly, BooksCorpus and English Wikipedia
  • GPT Pre-Training Tasks:
    • Predict the next token, given the previous tokens
    • More learning signals than MLM
  • GPT Pre-Training Results:
    • GPT ‚Äì 117M Params
    • Similarly competitive on GLUE and SQuAD
  • GPT-3: Generalizes to more tasks, not just more inputs!
  • Uses only the decoder of the transformer as an LM‚Äì ‚ÄúTransformer w/o aux LM‚Äù
  • Large performance improvement in many tasks
  • Add Task conditioning: put the nature of task in the input (not just LM)
    (Parameters x1000)
  • The Effectiveness of Self-Supervised Learning
    • The model seems to be able to learn from generating the language itself, rather than from any specific task we might cook up
  • Language Model as a Knowledge Base
    • A generatively pretrained model seems to have a decent zero-shot performance on a range of NLP tasks

And scaling works!!!

The LLM Era ‚ÄìParadigm Shift in ML

Vision Transformer (ViT)
  • Divide your image in patches with positional encodings
  • Apply Self-Attention

Decoding

  • Greedy: pick the YtY_tYt‚ÄãÔªø with the highest probability
  • Top-K/ Top-p pruning
    • at each time, retain only the top-K (vocabs) or top-p (probability) scoring forks
    • Paths cannot continue once the output an <eos>
      ‚Üí So paths may be different lengths

      ‚Üí Select the most likely sequence ending in <eos> across all terminating sequences

  • Beam search
    • Slightly more efficient.
    • Does not perform redundant context computation
     # Assuming encoder output H = h[1]‚Ä¶ h
 [T] is available
 in
 path = <sos>
 beam = {path}
 pathscore = [path] = 1
 
 state[path] = h[0]  # initial state (computed using your favorite method)
 do  # Step forward
	 nextbeam = {}
	 nextpathscore = []
	 nextstate = {}
	 for path in beam:
		 cfin = path[end]
		 hpath = state[path]
		 C = compute_context_with_attention(hpath, H)
		 y,h = RNN_decode_step(hpath, cfin, C)
		 for c in Symbolset
			 newpath = path + c
			 nextstate[newpath] = h
			 nextpathscore[newpath] = pathscore[path]*y[c]
			 nextbeam += newpath # Set addition
		 end
	 end
	 beam, pathscore, state, bestpath = prune(nextstate,nextpathscore,nextbeam)
 until bestpath[end] = <eos>
VAE (L20, Nov 8- L22, Nov 15)
Learning Representation

Non-linear separable data

‚Üí no hard linear classifier correctly separate the samples

‚Üí consider p(y‚à£x)p(y|x)p(y‚à£x)Ôªø, y={0,1}y=\{0,1\}y={0,1}Ôªø rather than y=f(x)y = f(x)y=f(x)Ôªø

  • Potentially more realistic

  • 1D example
    • At each point look at a small
      window around that point
    • Plot the average value within the window‚Äì This is an approximation of the probability of 1 at that point

    ‚áí sigmoid function

(linearly inseparable)

  • Given training data (X1,y1),‚Ä¶,(XN,yN)(X_1,y_1),\dots, (X_N,y_N)(X1‚Äã,y1‚Äã),‚Ä¶,(XN‚Äã,yN‚Äã)Ôªø, XXXÔªøs are vectors, yyyÔªøs are binary class values
  • Maximum likelihood estimation ‚áî\Leftrightarrow‚áîÔªø minimizing KL divergence between desired output yiy_iyi‚ÄãÔªø & actual output 11+e‚àíyi(w0+wTXi)\frac{1}{1+e^{-y_i (w_0+\mathbf{w}^T X_i)}}1+e‚àíyi‚Äã(w0‚Äã+wTXi‚Äã)1‚ÄãÔªø

‚Üí no closed-form solution, need gradient descent

  • Consider separable case
    • For a ‚Äúsufficient‚Äù net, the final perceptron is a linear classifier

      (The rest of the network may be viewed as a transformation that transforms data from non-linear classes to linearly separable feature)

    • The data are (almost) linearly separable in the space of YYYÔªø
    • The network until the second-to-last layer is a non-linear function f(X)f(X)f(X)Ôªø
      that converts the input space
      XXXÔªø into the feature space YYYÔªø where the classes are maximally linearly separable.
    • For binary problems, using an SVM with slack at the final layer may be more effective than a final perceptron!
      • Option 1: First train the MLP with a perceptron at the output, then detach the feature extraction,
        compute features, and train an SVM
      • Option 2: Directly employ a max-margin rule at the output, and optimize the entire network

What do hidden layers learn?

  • Manifold hypothesis: For separable classes, the classes are linearly separable on a
    non-linear manifold
  • Layers sequentially ‚Äústraighten‚Äù the data manifold ‚Äì Until the final layer, which fully linearizes it

‚Üí affine transformation

The perceptron fires if the input is within a specified angle of the weight

  • Neuron fires if the input vector is close enough to the weight
    vector.
  • If the input pattern matches the weight pattern closely enough - i.e. If the input pattern and weight pattern are sufficiently correlated
  • The perceptron is a correlation filter!

‚ÄúAutoencoder‚Äù

= A neural network trained to predict the input itself

‚Üí Finds the direction of maximum energy

‚Üí In higher dimension without non-linear activations, it is still PCA.

  • Encoder learns to detect all the most significant patterns in the signals - The ‚ÄúAnalysis‚Äù net which computes the hidden representation
  • Decoder recomposes the signal from the patterns - The ‚ÄúSynthesis‚Äù which recomposes the data from the
    hidden representation

The simplest Autoencoder with a single hidden unit = PCA (All input vectors are mapped onto a point on the
principal axis, which minimize error)

x^=wTwx\hat{x} = w^T w xx^=wTwxÔªø

div(x^,x)=‚à£‚à£x‚àíwTwx‚à£‚à£2div(\hat{x}, x) = ||x - w^Tw x||^2div(x^,x)=‚à£‚à£x‚àíwTwx‚à£‚à£2Ôªø

‚áíw^=arg‚Å°min‚Å°E(‚à£‚à£x‚àíwTwx‚à£‚à£2)‚áí \hat{w} = \arg\min \mathbb{E} (||x-w^T w x||^2)‚áíw^=argminE(‚à£‚à£x‚àíwTwx‚à£‚à£2)Ôªø

  • With non-linearity ‚Üí ‚Äúnon-linear‚Äù PCA
  • Deeper networks can capture more complicated manifolds
  • Examples
    • 2D spiral
      • 2 hidden layers of 100 neurons
      • not generalize beyond the manifold - extending hidden latent space beyond the values seen in training doesn‚Äôt extend the helix
    • Signal separation (separating music): Given a mixed sound from multiple sources, separate out the sources
      • Any values applied to the (hidden) input to the decoder will produce data similar to the training data
      • Learn a dictionary of ‚Äúbuilding blocks‚Äù for each sound source
      • A mixed signal is the linear combination of signals from the individual sources‚Äì Which are in turn composed of entries from its
        dictionary

Variational Autoencoder (VAE)

Want: model the distribution of any data - so that we can draw samples from it!

Some ‚Äúsimple‚Äù generative model

  • PMF like Poisson distribution (parameter Œª\lambdaŒªÔªø)
  • Gaussian PDF (parameters Œº,Œ£\mu, \SigmaŒº,Œ£Ôªø)

‚áí estimate parameters with Maximum Likelihood Estimation (MLE): arg‚Å°max‚Å°Œ∏log‚Å°P(X;Œ∏)\arg\max_{\theta} \log P(X;\theta)argmaxŒ∏‚ÄãlogP(X;Œ∏)Ôªø

MLE with incomplete data

Sometimes the data provided may be incomplete ‚Ä¶

‚áí insufficient to write out the complete log probability

‚áí insufficient to estimate model parameters directly

  • Data vectors have some missing components

    Goal: Estimate a Gaussian distribution from a collection of vectors

    • Given O={o1,‚Ä¶,oN}O= \{o_1,\dots, o_N\}O={o1‚Äã,‚Ä¶,oN‚Äã}Ôªø set of incomplete vectors (comprising only the observed components of the data)
    • Missing M={m1,‚Ä¶,mN}M= \{m_1,\dots,m_N\}M={m1‚Äã,‚Ä¶,mN‚Äã}Ôªø
    • Complete data set X={x1,‚Ä¶,xN}X = \{x_1,\dots,x_N\}X={x1‚Äã,‚Ä¶,xN‚Äã}Ôªø where xi=(oi,mi)x_i = (o_i,m_i)xi‚Äã=(oi‚Äã,mi‚Äã)Ôªø

    ‚áíP(o)=‚à´P(x)dm=‚à´P(o,m)dm‚áí P(o) = \int P(x) dm = \int P(o,m) dm‚áíP(o)=‚à´P(x)dm=‚à´P(o,m)dmÔªø

    • No closed-form solution!!!
    • Need efficient iterative algorithms

    ‚ÄúExpand‚Äù every incomplete vectors out into all possibilities

    • In appropriate proportions P(m‚à£o)P(m|o)P(m‚à£o)Ôªø from estimate of the model

    Estimate the statistics from the expanded data

    • Let xi(m)x_i(m)xi‚Äã(m)Ôªø be the ‚Äúcompleted‚Äù version of the observations oio_ioi‚ÄãÔªø, when the missing components are filled with value mmmÔªø
    • For each oio_ioi‚ÄãÔªø, the number of xi(m)‚àùP(m‚à£o;Œ∏k)x_i(m) \propto P(m|o;\theta^k)xi‚Äã(m)‚àùP(m‚à£o;Œ∏k)Ôªø for each mmmÔªø
  • Structure of the model ‚Äì Mixture models, multi-stage Generative models
    • Mixture of Gaussians (GMM)

      P(o)=‚àëkP(k,o)=‚àëkP(k)N(o;Œºk,œÉk2)P(o) = \sum_k P(k,o) = \sum_k P(k) \mathcal{N} (o; \mu_k,\sigma_k^2)P(o)=‚àëk‚ÄãP(k,o)=‚àëk‚ÄãP(k)N(o;Œºk‚Äã,œÉk2‚Äã)Ôªø

      • Missing information about kkkÔªø
    • The general form Œ∏^=arg‚Å°max‚Å°Œ∏‚àëolog‚Å°‚àëhP(h,o)\hat{\theta} =\arg\max_{\theta} \sum_o \log\sum_h P(h,o)Œ∏^=argmaxŒ∏‚Äã‚àëo‚Äãlog‚àëh‚ÄãP(h,o)Ôªø
      • log‚Å°P(o)=log‚Å°‚àëhQ(h)P(h,o)Q(h)\log P(o) = \log \sum_h Q(h)\frac{P(h,o)}{Q(h)}logP(o)=log‚àëh‚ÄãQ(h)Q(h)P(h,o)‚ÄãÔªø, where some function Q(h)>0Q(h) >0Q(h)>0Ôªø and ‚àëhQ(h)=1\sum_h Q(h) = 1‚àëh‚ÄãQ(h)=1Ôªø.
      • Note that log‚Å°\loglogÔªø is concave, i.e. log‚Å°(Œªx1+(1‚àíŒª)x2)‚â•Œªlog‚Å°x1+(1‚àíŒª)log‚Å°x2\log(\lambda x_1 + (1-\lambda) x_2) \geq \lambda \log x_1 + (1-\lambda) \log x_2log(Œªx1‚Äã+(1‚àíŒª)x2‚Äã)‚â•Œªlogx1‚Äã+(1‚àíŒª)logx2‚ÄãÔªø, Œª‚àà(0,1)\lambda \in (0,1)Œª‚àà(0,1)Ôªø

      ‚áí Evidence Lower Bound (ELBO) on log‚Å°P(o) \log P(o)logP(o)Ôªø

    • Complete the data by attributing to every Gaussian‚Äì i.e. make many complete ‚Äúclones‚Äù of the data
      • But assign a proportion to each completed vector‚Äì Proportion is from previous estimate of model
        • Which can be computed if we know ùëÉ(ùëò)and ùëÉ(ùëú|ùëò)
        • Then estimate the parameters using the complete data
    • ‚ÄúComplete‚Äù each vector: assign each vector to every Gaussian‚Äì In proportion ùëÉ(ùëò‚à£ùëú;ùúÉ)ùëÉ(ùëò|ùëú;ùúÉ)P(k‚à£o;ùúÉ)Ôªø (computed from current model estimate)
    • Compute statistics from ‚Äúcompleted‚Äù data

Expectation-Maximization (EM algorithm)
  1. Determine Q(x)Q(x)Q(x)Ôªø that maximize the RHS, using current Œ∏\thetaŒ∏Ôªø (make the bound tight)
    • Solve ‚àáQ(h)RHS=0\nabla_{Q(h)} RHS = 0‚àáQ(h)‚ÄãRHS=0Ôªø, Q(h)‚â•0Q(h) ‚â• 0Q(h)‚â•0Ôªø, ‚àëhQ(h)=1\sum_h Q(h) = 1‚àëh‚ÄãQ(h)=1Ôªø if close form solution exists
    • If Q(h)Q(h)Q(h)Ôªø is modelled by a NN, perform gradient descent with backpropagation.
    • For any P(h,o;Œ∏)P(h,o;\theta)P(h,o;Œ∏)Ôªø, the optimal Q(h)=P(h‚à£o;Œ∏)Q(h) = P(h|o;\theta)Q(h)=P(h‚à£o;Œ∏)Ôªø (LHS = RHS)
      • Let Q(h)=P(h‚à£o;Œ∏‚Äô)Q(h) = P(h|o;\theta‚Äô)Q(h)=P(h‚à£o;Œ∏‚Äô)Ôªø, then

      log‚Å°P(o;Œ∏)‚â•‚àëhP(h‚à£o;Œ∏‚Äô)log‚Å°P(h,o;Œ∏)P(h‚à£o;Œ∏‚Äô):=J(Œ∏,Œ∏‚Äô)\log P(o;\theta) ‚â• \sum_h P(h|o;\theta‚Äô) \log \frac{P(h,o; \theta)}{P(h|o;\theta‚Äô)} := J(\theta,\theta‚Äô)logP(o;Œ∏)‚â•‚àëh‚ÄãP(h‚à£o;Œ∏‚Äô)logP(h‚à£o;Œ∏‚Äô)P(h,o;Œ∏)‚Äã:=J(Œ∏,Œ∏‚Äô)Ôªø

      ‚Üí Note that log‚Å°P(o;Œ∏)=J(Œ∏,Œ∏)\log P(o;\theta) = J(\theta,\theta)logP(o;Œ∏)=J(Œ∏,Œ∏)Ôªø

  1. Fix Q(h)Q(h)Q(h)Ôªø and maximize the RHS w.r.t Œ∏\thetaŒ∏Ôªø

‚Üí each step guaranteed to increase log‚Å°P(o;Œ∏)\log P(o;\theta)logP(o;Œ∏)Ôªø, stop when log‚Å°P(o;Œ∏) \log P(o;\theta)logP(o;Œ∏)Ôªø stop increasing

Overall EM principle

  • Initially, some data/information are missing
  • Initialize model parameters
  • Iterate
    • Complete the data according to the posterior probabilities ùëÉ(ùëö‚à£ùëú)ùëÉ(ùëö|ùëú)P(m‚à£o)Ôªø computed by the current model
      • By implicitly considering every possible value, with its posterior-based proportionality
      • Or by explicit completion through sampling the posterior probability distribution P(m‚à£o)P(m|o)P(m‚à£o)Ôªø
    • Re-estimate the model
PCA

Find the principal subspace such that when all vectors are approximated
as lying on that subspace, the approximation error is minimal
- Assuming ‚Äúcentered‚Äù (zero-mean) data

  • Close-form solution exists

    Let ‚àáwLoss=0‚áí(‚àëxxTx)w=Œªw\nabla_w Loss = 0 ‚áí \left(\sum_x x^T x\right) w = \lambda w‚àáw‚ÄãLoss=0‚áí(‚àëx‚ÄãxTx)w=ŒªwÔªø where Œª\lambdaŒªÔªø is eigenvalue of the projection.

The estimation is scale invariant

  • We can increase the length of w, and compensate it by reducing z

Let W‚Äô=WB,Z‚Äô=B‚àí1(Z)W‚Äô = WB, Z‚Äô = B^{-1}(Z)W‚Äô=WB,Z‚Äô=B‚àí1(Z)Ôªø, then WZ=(WB)(B‚àí1Z)=W‚ÄôZ‚ÄôWZ = (WB)(B^{-1} Z) = W‚Äô Z‚ÄôWZ=(WB)(B‚àí1Z)=W‚ÄôZ‚ÄôÔªø, for arbitrary BBBÔªø (a different set of bases for the same subspace)

  • The representation of the bases is not unique!
  • To make it unique, we can either

‚Üí constrain vectors in W to be unit length & orthogonal ‚áí standard ‚Äúclosed‚Äù form in PCA

‚Üí constrain the variance of Z to be unity

The iterative algorithm

  • Initialize a subspace (the basis wwwÔªø)
  • Iterate until convergence:
    • Find the best position vectors ZZZÔªø
      on the subspace
      WWWÔªø for each training instance (complete the data with appropriate ZZZÔªø)
      • Find the location on WWWÔªø that is closest to each instance, i.e. the perpendicular projection
    • Let W rotate and stretch/shrink, keeping the arrangement of ZZZÔªø locations fixed (re-estimate WWWÔªø given ZZZÔªø)
      • Minimize the total square length of the lines attaching the projection on the place to the instance
  • The linear AE can be constrained to give unique solution (i.e. variance of ZZZÔªø is unity)

  • Generative story of linear AEs
    • Draw zzzÔªø from a K-dim isotropic Gaussian (K = dim of the principal subspace)
    • A = PCA ‚Äúbasis‚Äù matrix (of principal eigenvectors, scaled by eigenvalues)
    • E = 0-mean & low-rank covariance Gaussian noise, orthogonal to principal subspace
    • If zzzÔªø is Gaussian, X^\hat{X}X^Ôªø is Gaussian
    • X^\hat{X}X^Ôªø & EEEÔªø are Gaussian ‚Üí XXXÔªø is Gaussian

    PCA assumes the noise is always orthogonal to the data

    • Not always true
    • Noise in images can look like images, random noise can sound like speech, etc.

    Factor Analysis (linear Gaussian model (LGM)):

    ‚Üí generalize the model to permit non-orthogonal noise

    To generate any point

    • Take a Gaussian step on the hyperplane
    • Add full-rank Gaussian uncorrelated noise (diagonal covariance matrix) that is independent of the position on the hyperplane

    x=Az+E‚áíx‚àºN(0,AAT+D)x = Az + E ‚áí x\sim \mathcal{N}(0,AA^T+D)x=Az+E‚áíx‚àºN(0,AAT+D)Ôªø

    P(x‚à£z)=N(Az,D)P(x|z) = \mathcal{N}(Az, D)P(x‚à£z)=N(Az,D)Ôªø

    • Direction of noise is unconstrained (can lie in any direction) - need not be orthogonal to the plane

    ‚Üí The way to produce any data instance is no longer unique, though different corrections may have different probabilities

    • zzzÔªø are the factors

    Parameters

    • AAAÔªø is the loading matrix
    • DDDÔªø is diagonal
    • The probability density of x is Gaussian lying mostly close to a hyperplane - with uncorrelated Gaussian noise
  • Estimating A,DA, DA,DÔªø via MLE with known zzzÔªø

Differentiating w.r.t A, D and equating to 0, we get

  • EM for LGM with unknown zzzÔªø
    • Complete the data by
      • In every possible way proportional to P(z‚à£x)=N(z;AT(AAT+D)‚àí1x,I‚àíAT(AAT+D)‚àí1A)P(z|x) = \mathcal{N} (z; A^T(AA^T+D)^{-1} x, I - A^T(AA^T+D)^{-1} A)P(z‚à£x)=N(z;AT(AAT+D)‚àí1x,I‚àíAT(AAT+D)‚àí1A)Ôªø

      ‚áí Objective: arg‚Å°max‚Å°A,D‚àëx‚à´zp(z‚à£x)(log‚Å°‚à£D‚à£‚àí(x‚àíAz)TD‚àí1(x‚àíAz))dz\arg\max_{A,D} \sum_{x} \int_z p(z|x)\left( \log|D| - (x-Az)^T D^{-1} (x-Az) \right) dzargmaxA,D‚Äã‚àëx‚Äã‚à´z‚Äãp(z‚à£x)(log‚à£D‚à£‚àí(x‚àíAz)TD‚àí1(x‚àíAz))dzÔªø

      • Drawing samples of missing component from P(z‚à£x;Ak,Dk)N(z;(Ak)T(Ak(Ak)T+Dk)‚àí1x,I‚àí(Ak)T(Ak(Ak)T+Dk)‚àí1Ak)P(z|x; A^k, D^k) \mathcal{N} (z; (A^k)^T(A^k(A^k)^T+D^k)^{-1} x, I - (A^k)^T(A^k(A^k)^T+D^k)^{-1} A^k)P(z‚à£x;Ak,Dk)N(z;(Ak)T(Ak(Ak)T+Dk)‚àí1x,I‚àí(Ak)T(Ak(Ak)T+Dk)‚àí1Ak)Ôªø and estimate parameters from the ‚Äúcompleted‚Äù data

The pipeline for VAE

‚Üí What about data that are not Gaussian distributed close to a curved or otherwise non-linear manifold rather than a plane?

f(z) is a non-linear function

  1. Find a function that warps a lower-dimensional input plane to the target manifold in the data space
  1. Transform a Gaussian distribution on the input plane to a distribution on the curved manifold
  1. Add some uncorrelated Gaussian ‚Äúfuzz‚Äù to account for off manifold variations

Issues:

  • Select (or guess) the dimensionality of the manifold
  • Choosing the right function f(z) that is capable of learning the shape of the manifold
  • EM for NLGM

    ‚Üí zzzÔªø is unobserved

    ‚Üí Complete the data by drawing samples from P(z‚à£x)=P(x‚à£z)P(z)P(x)P(z|x) = \frac{P(x|z)P(z)}{P(x)} P(z‚à£x)=P(x)P(x‚à£z)P(z)‚ÄãÔªø

    But P(x)=‚à´(x;f(z;Œ∏),D)N(z;0,D)dzP(x) = \int \mathcal(x; f(z;\theta),D)\mathcal{N}(z;0,D) dzP(x)=‚à´(x;f(z;Œ∏),D)N(z;0,D)dzÔªø is intractable for most f(z;Œ∏)f(z;\theta)f(z;Œ∏)Ôªø!!!

    ‚Üí Assume Œ£(x;œï) \Sigma(x;\phi)Œ£(x;œï)Ôªø is diagonal for simplicity

    Let P(z‚à£x)‚âàQ(z,x)=N(z;Œº(x),Œ£(x))P(z|x) \approx Q(z,x) = \mathcal{N}(z;\mu(x), \Sigma(x))P(z‚à£x)‚âàQ(z,x)=N(z;Œº(x),Œ£(x))Ôªø

    • Initialize f(z;Œ∏)f(z;\theta)f(z;Œ∏)Ôªø
    • Iterate
      • Estimate Œº(x;œÜ),Œ£(x;œÜ)\mu(x;\varphi), \Sigma(x;\varphi)Œº(x;œÜ),Œ£(x;œÜ)Ôªø that give the best Q(z,x)Q(z,x)Q(z,x)Ôªø

      • Re-estimate f(z;Œ∏)f(z;\theta)f(z;Œ∏)Ôªø
  • The generative model
    • some math derivation

    Complete objective function to estimate Œ∏\thetaŒ∏Ôªø and œÜ\varphiœÜÔªø

    Initialize Œ∏\thetaŒ∏Ôªø & œÜ\varphiœÜÔªø

    Iterate

      ‚Üí Compute Œº(x;œÜ),Œ£(x;œÜ)\mu(x;\varphi),\Sigma(x;\varphi)Œº(x;œÜ),Œ£(x;œÜ)Ôªø

      ‚Üí draw œµ‚àºN(0,IK)\epsilon \sim \mathcal{N}(0,I_K)œµ‚àºN(0,IK‚Äã)Ôªø

      Œ∏‚àó,œÉ‚àó2=arg‚Å°min‚Å°Œ∏,œÉ2L(Œ∏,œÉ2)\theta^*, {\sigma^*}^2 = \arg\min_{\theta,{\sigma}^2} L(\theta,\sigma^2)Œ∏‚àó,œÉ‚àó2=argminŒ∏,œÉ2‚ÄãL(Œ∏,œÉ2)Ôªø

Diffusion & Flow (L23, Nov 20)

Given a data distribution pppÔªø that is a mixture of two 2D gaussians as shown below in red. We want to approximate this with one gaussian estimate qqqÔªø by minimizing KL-divergence DKL(p‚à£‚à£q)D_{KL} (p||q)DKL‚Äã(p‚à£‚à£q)Ôªø

Diffusion model

Markovian Hierarchical Variational Autoencoder (MHVAEs) - with restrictions:

  • Latent dimension is the same as the data dimension
  • The encoder has no parameters to be learnt. It is defined to be a linear gaussian such that the ùë°-ùë°‚Ñé gaussian is centered around the previous latent zùë°‚àí1z_{ùë°‚àí1}zt‚àí1‚ÄãÔªø
  • The parameters for the gaussians are scheduled such that the final latent is a standard gaussian zT‚àí1‚àºN(zT;0,I)z_{T-1} \sim \mathcal{N}(z_T;0,I)zT‚àí1‚Äã‚àºN(zT‚Äã;0,I)Ôªø

Generative process

Diffusion Process (tractable)

Update ELBO

  • Reconstruction: Reconstruction from least noisy version (hyperparameter choice can make this arbitrarily small)
  • Prior matching: Moving the posterior closer to the true prior on the final noisy step (0 for diffusion models)
  • Denoising: Divergence between approximate denoising (ùëùùúÉ) and true denoising (ùëû) steps
    • Let Lt=DKL(q(xt‚àí1‚à£xt,x0)‚à£‚à£pŒ∏(xt‚àí1‚à£xt))=Eq(12Œ£t‚à£‚à£ŒºÀât‚àíŒºŒ∏(xt,t)‚à£‚à£2)L_t = D_{KL} (q(x_{t-1}|x_t,x_0)||p_{\theta}(x_{t-1}|x_t)) = \mathbb{E}_q\left(\frac{1}{2\Sigma_t} ||\bar{\mu}_t - \mu_{\theta} (x_t,t)||^2\right)Lt‚Äã=DKL‚Äã(q(xt‚àí1‚Äã‚à£xt‚Äã,x0‚Äã)‚à£‚à£pŒ∏‚Äã(xt‚àí1‚Äã‚à£xt‚Äã))=Eq‚Äã(2Œ£t‚Äã1‚Äã‚à£‚à£ŒºÀâ‚Äãt‚Äã‚àíŒºŒ∏‚Äã(xt‚Äã,t)‚à£‚à£2)Ôªø
    • Note that xt=Œ±txt‚àí1+1‚àíŒ±tœµx_t = \sqrt{\alpha_t} x_{t-1} + \sqrt{1-\alpha_t} \epsilonxt‚Äã=Œ±t‚Äã‚Äãxt‚àí1‚Äã+1‚àíŒ±t‚Äã‚ÄãœµÔªø, œµ‚àºN(0,I)\epsilon\sim \mathcal{N}(0,I)œµ‚àºN(0,I)Ôªø

      ‚áí ŒºÀât=1Œ±t(xt‚àí1‚àíŒ±t1‚àíŒ±Àâtœµ)\bar{\mu}_t = \frac{1}{\sqrt{\alpha_t}} \left(x_t - \frac{1-\alpha_t}{\sqrt{1-\bar{\alpha}_t}}\epsilon \right)ŒºÀâ‚Äãt‚Äã=Œ±t‚Äã‚Äã1‚Äã(xt‚Äã‚àí1‚àíŒ±Àât‚Äã‚Äã1‚àíŒ±t‚Äã‚Äãœµ)Ôªø

      ŒºŒ∏(xt,t)=1Œ±t(xt‚àí1‚àíŒ±t1‚àíŒ±ÀâtœµŒ∏(xt,t))\mu_{\theta}(x_t,t) = \frac{1}{\sqrt{\alpha_t}} \left(x_t - \frac{1-\alpha_t}{\sqrt{1-\bar{\alpha}_t} }\epsilon_{\theta} (x_t,t) \right)ŒºŒ∏‚Äã(xt‚Äã,t)=Œ±t‚Äã‚Äã1‚Äã(xt‚Äã‚àí1‚àíŒ±Àât‚Äã‚Äã1‚àíŒ±t‚Äã‚ÄãœµŒ∏‚Äã(xt‚Äã,t))Ôªø

Normalizing Flows

(Maximize likelihood estimation)

  • z=g(x)z = g(x)z=g(x)Ôªø determines where a point in x-space maps to z-space

z‚àºp(z)z \sim p(z)z‚àºp(z)Ôªø

x=fT‚àòfT‚àí1‚àò‚ãØ‚àòf1(z)x = f_T \circ f_{T-1} \circ \dots \circ f_1(z)x=fT‚Äã‚àòfT‚àí1‚Äã‚àò‚ãØ‚àòf1‚Äã(z)Ôªø

‚áíz=g1‚àòg2‚àò‚ãØ‚àògT(x)‚áí z = g_1 \circ g_2 \circ \dots \circ g_T (x)‚áíz=g1‚Äã‚àòg2‚Äã‚àò‚ãØ‚àògT‚Äã(x)Ôªø =f‚àí1(x)= f^{-1}(x)=f‚àí1(x)Ôªø

Normally, compute determinant is O(n3),\mathcal{O}(n^3),O(n3),Ôªø with n=n =n=Ôªø dimension of the matrix, but only is O(n)\mathcal{O}(n)O(n)Ôªø for triangular or diagonal matrix.

For a good (efficient) flow, we must have functions (steps) that are:

  1. Expressive
  1. Invertible
  1. Offer cheap to compute Jacobian determinants
  • Construction with a shuffle

    (to avoid x1x_1x1‚ÄãÔªø just passing along unchanged along the flow, still invertible by multiplying to a permutation matrix)

Coupling Flow ‚Äì Used in implementations such as NICE and GLOW

  • E.g. GLOW
    • Multiscale architecture
    • Split along channels
    • Employ CNNs
    • Perform permutations using 1x1 Conv layers
GAN (L24, Nov 27 - L25, Dec 2)

Given a distribution of inputs X and labels Y

Explicit distribution models

  • Calculate P(x‚àºX)P(x\sim X)P(x‚àºX)Ôªø for all xxxÔªø

Implicit distribution models

  • Generate x‚àºXx\sim Xx‚àºXÔªø

Generative Adversarial Networks (GAN) (since 2014)

  • Generative Models which generate data similar to the training data.
    E.g. Variational Autoencoders (VAE)
  • Adversarial Training: two competing networks (adversaries) that are trying beat each other.
    • Generator input (latent vector) Z can be sampled from a known prior, e.g. standard Gaussian

Goal: PG(X)=PX(X)P_G(X) = P_X(X)PG‚Äã(X)=PX‚Äã(X)Ôªø, i.e. generated distribution matches true distribution

  • Generator is a VAE decoder
    • Maximizing the likelihood of the data

      Œ∏‚àó=arg‚Å°min‚Å°‚àílog‚Å°P(X;Œ∏)\theta^* = \arg \min -\log P(X;\theta)Œ∏‚àó=argmin‚àílogP(X;Œ∏)Ôªø

    • Likelihood maximization does not implies whether the output actually looks like a real image (a face)

    ‚áí DILLAF loss (Discriminator)

    • Training‚Ä¶
      • Discriminator‚Äôs loss is backpropagated to the generator
      • Maximize the discriminator loss
        • {D(G(Z))=1,1‚àíD(G(Z))=0 \begin{cases} D(G(Z)) = 1, \\1- D(G(Z)) = 0\end{cases}{D(G(Z))=1,1‚àíD(G(Z))=0‚ÄãÔªø
        • Minimize log‚Å°(1‚àíD(X^))\log (1-D(\hat{X}))log(1‚àíD(X^))Ôªø (want D(X^)=D(G(Z))=1D(\hat{X}) = D(G(Z))=1D(X^)=D(G(Z))=1Ôªø)
  • Discriminator is trained to tell the difference between real and generated (fake) data
    • If a perfect discriminator is fooled, the generated data cannot be distinguished from real data
    • Training‚Ä¶
      • Inputs: training examples of real & synthetic faces
      • Minimize error between actual & predicted labels (classification loss)
        • D(X)={1,if¬†X¬†is¬†real0,syntheticD(X) = \begin{cases} 1, & \text{if $X$ is real} \\0, & \text{synthetic}\end{cases}D(X)={1,0,‚Äãif¬†X¬†is¬†realsynthetic‚ÄãÔªø
        • Maximize log‚Å°D(X)\log D(X)logD(X)Ôªø for real, log‚Å°(1‚àíD(X))\log (1-D(X))log(1‚àíD(X))Ôªø for synthetic.

GAN objective function

  • The perfect discriminator

    P(yi‚à£X)=P(X,yi)P(X,y1)+P(X,y2)P(y_i|X) = \frac{P(X,y_i)}{P(X,y_1) + P(X,y_2)}P(yi‚Äã‚à£X)=P(X,y1‚Äã)+P(X,y2‚Äã)P(X,yi‚Äã)‚ÄãÔªø

    Perfect decision boundary is where P(X,y1)=P(X,y2)P(X,y_1) = P(X,y_2)P(X,y1‚Äã)=P(X,y2‚Äã)Ôªø

  • Updating the generator (fool the discriminator)

    ‚Üí Moving the generator into the region assigned to the other class by the (perfect) discriminator

  • Iteratively‚Ä¶

Min-max Optimization

where JS(PX,PG)JS(P_X,P_G)JS(PX‚Äã,PG‚Äã)Ôªø is the Jensen-Shannon divergence between PX(X)P_X(X)PX‚Äã(X)Ôªø and PG(X)P_G(X)PG‚Äã(X)Ôªø.

  • Jensen-Shannon divergence
    • JS(P,Q)=12KL(P,12(P+Q))+12KL(Q,12(P+Q))JS(P,Q) = \frac{1}{2} KL\left(P,\frac{1}{2} (P+Q)\right)+ \frac{1}{2} KL\left(Q,\frac{1}{2} (P+Q)\right)JS(P,Q)=21‚ÄãKL(P,21‚Äã(P+Q))+21‚ÄãKL(Q,21‚Äã(P+Q))Ôªø for probability distributions P,QP,QP,QÔªø.
    • KL(P,Q)=‚àëXP(X)log‚Å°P(X)Q(X)KL(P,Q) = \sum_X P(X) \log\frac{P(X)}{Q(X)}KL(P,Q)=‚àëX‚ÄãP(X)logQ(X)P(X)‚ÄãÔªø blows up when Q(X)=0Q(X) = 0Q(X)=0Ôªø.
  • Stationary point
    • If PG(X)=PX(X)P_G(X) = P_X(X)PG‚Äã(X)=PX‚Äã(X)Ôªø (global minima), D(X)=0.5D(X) = 0.5D(X)=0.5Ôªø for all XXXÔªø (i.e. discriminator converges)

    ‚áí‚áí‚áíÔªø ‚àáXD(X)=0\nabla_X D(X) = 0‚àáX‚ÄãD(X)=0Ôªø

    • This is also true of a random discriminator :(((
    • Stationary points need not be stable (depends on the exact GANs formulation and other factors)
      • Generator may overshoot some values or oscillate around the optimum
      • A discriminator with unlimited capacity can still assign an arbitrarily large distance to 2 similar distributions.
  • Generator and the discriminator need to be trained simultaneously
    • If discriminator is undertrained, it provides sub-optimal feedback to the generator
    • If discriminator is over-trained, there is no local feedback for marginal improvements
Pros & Cons

VAEs

  • Minimizing the KL divergence between distributions of synthetic and true data
  • Uses an encoder to predict latent
    distributions to optimize generator
  • More complex formulation
  • Simpler optimization. Trains faster and
    more reliably
  • Results are blurry

GANs

  • Minimizing the Jenson-Shannon
    divergence between distributions of
    synthetic and true data
  • Use a discriminator to optimize
    generator
  • Simpler formulation
  • Noisy and difficult optimization
  • Sharper results
  • ‚ÄúMode collapse‚Äù are frequent - producing outputs with very low variability

Training‚Ä¶

  • As the Discriminator gets more and more confident, the region that gives us informative gradients keeps shrinking.
  • No gradient information to further update the Generator after the Discriminator got too confident.
  • How to improve?
    • Consider the worst case: 2 distributions P and Q such that they are only 1 for 1 value of x and 0 otherwise. Let Œ∏\thetaŒ∏Ôªø be the distance between the peaks of these distributions.
      • KL(P‚à£‚à£Q)={0,Œ∏=0‚àû,Œ∏‚â†0KL(P||Q) = \begin{cases} 0, & \theta =0\\ \infty, & \theta \neq 0\end{cases}KL(P‚à£‚à£Q)={0,‚àû,‚ÄãŒ∏=0Œ∏ÓÄ†=0‚ÄãÔªø
      • JS(P‚à£‚à£Q)={0,Œ∏=0log‚Å°(2),Œ∏‚â†0JS(P||Q) = \begin{cases} 0, & \theta =0\\ \log(2), & \theta \neq 0\end{cases}JS(P‚à£‚à£Q)={0,log(2),‚ÄãŒ∏=0Œ∏ÓÄ†=0‚ÄãÔªø

    ‚áí Wasserstein distance (WassersteinGAN)

    where Œì\GammaŒìÔªø is the functional space that maps PXP_XPX‚ÄãÔªø to PGP_GPG‚ÄãÔªø.

    Goal: Find the optimal mapping/ transport.

    • But unknown PXP_XPX‚ÄãÔªø & complex Œ≥\gammaŒ≥Ôªø.

    Kantorovich-Rubinstein duality

    where ‚à£‚à£f‚à£‚à£L‚â§1||f||_L ‚â§ 1‚à£‚à£f‚à£‚à£L‚Äã‚â§1Ôªø is set of 1-Lipschitz scalar functions.

    ‚áí Clipping to make fffÔªø 1-Lipschitz

    1. Update D(Œ∏D)D(\theta_D)D(Œ∏D‚Äã)Ôªø using gradient of EX[D(x)]‚àíEZ[D(G(z)))]\mathbb{E}_X [ D(x)] - \mathbb{E}_Z[ D(G(z)))] EX‚Äã[D(x)]‚àíEZ‚Äã[D(G(z)))]Ôªø
    1. Clip all the weight in Œ∏D\theta_DŒ∏D‚ÄãÔªø to some [‚àíc,c][-c,c][‚àíc,c]Ôªø
    1. Update G(Œ∏G)G(\theta_G)G(Œ∏G‚Äã)Ôªø to maximize EZ[D(G(z)))]\mathbb{E}_Z[ D(G(z)))] EZ‚Äã[D(G(z)))]Ôªø

    • If the clipping parameter is too large, then it takes too long to train the Discriminator to optimality.
    • If too small, then the gradients vanish before reaching the generator.

    ‚áí Gradient penalty

    • Push the norm of the gradient to be close to 1

    ‚áí Spectral norm

    • Enforce the Lipschitz constraint on the weights

      where œÉ(Wl)\sigma(W_l)œÉ(Wl‚Äã)Ôªø is the spectral norm of weight WlW_lWl‚ÄãÔªø.

    • The Lipschitz norm (the bound) for a composite function (NN) is upper bounded by the product of the Lipschitz norms of the composing functions (each layer).

Various versions

High fidelity natural images
(2019)

‚Üí High Resolution

StarGAN (2018)

‚Üí Better quality

  • Wasserstein GAN
  • StarGAN - Image-to-image translation

    Discriminator:

    1. Identify whether an image is fake or not.
    1. Predict the target domain of the input image.
      • Uses an auxiliary classifier to learn the mapping of original image and its corresponding domain from the dataset

    Generator:

    1. The images generated are realistic.
    1. The images generated are classifiable as target domain by D.
    1. Able to reconstruct the original image from the fake image given the original domain label. (Cycle consistency Loss)
  • Conditional GAN

    with class yyyÔªø associated with the input data and latent vectors.

    • Provides more control in what type of images are generated by the generator
    • Are not strictly unsupervised learning algorithms because they require labeled data as input to the additional layer
    • Able to generate the outputs for exactly the classes or labels that we desire

  • LapGAN (Laplacian GAN)
    • A chain of conditional GANs, to generate progressively larger images.
    • A conditional GAN generates larger images conditioned on the smaller image, repeated
      until you reach the desired size.
  • BiGAN
  • CycleGAN
    • Autoencoder alternative

    ‚áí CycleGAN

    • Cycle consistency loss (just a reconstruction loss)
      • Ensures that the generated image has retained enough information about the input enough to retrieve it using a different ‚Äúspecial purpose‚Äù generator
    • Image translation / Style transfer
    • For specific and small no. of images
    • Need a content and style image
    • Specific & small number of images

    • Just need 2 domains of images. No need for specific content or style
      images
    • Many similar pictures
    • Specificity of images doesn‚Äôt really matter
  • DCGAN

etc.

Hopfield Network

Analogy: Spin Glasses

  • Magnetic diploes in a disordered magnetic material
  • Total field at current dipole:

where pip_ipi‚ÄãÔªø is vector position of iiiÔªø-th dipole

  • Each dipole tries to align itself to the local field ‚Üí in doing so it may flip
  • This will change fields at other dipoles - which may flip ‚Üí changes the field at the current dipole‚Ä¶
    • Response of current dipole
  • The field at any dipole is the sum of the field contributions of all other dipoles
  • The contribution of a dipole to the field at any point depends on interaction ‚Äì Derived from the ‚ÄúIsing‚Äù model for magnetic materials (Ising and Lenz, 1924)
  • The ‚ÄúHamiltonian‚Äù (total energy) of the system
    • The system evolves to minimize the energy (could be at local minimum)
    • Dipoles stop flipping if any flips result in increase of energy

‚Üí Consider a loopy network (Hopfield Net)

  • At each time each neuron receives a ‚Äúfield‚Äù
  • If the sign of the field matches its own sign, it does not respond
  • If the sign of the field opposes its own sign, it ‚Äúflips‚Äù to match the sign of the field

  • Each neuron is a perceptron with +1/-1 output
  • Every neuron receives input from every other neuron
  • Every neuron outputs signals to every other neuron

yi‚Üí‚àíyiy_i ‚Üí -y_iyi‚Äã‚Üí‚àíyi‚ÄãÔªø if yi(‚àëj‚â†iwjiyj+bi)<0y_i(\sum_{j\neq i} w_{ji} y_j+b_i) <0yi‚Äã(‚àëjÓÄ†=i‚Äãwji‚Äãyj‚Äã+bi‚Äã)<0Ôªø

‚Üí But this may cause other neurons to flip!

Q: Will this behavior continue for ever??

  • Let yi‚àíy_i^{-}yi‚àí‚ÄãÔªø and yi+y^{+}_iyi+‚ÄãÔªø be the output of the iiiÔªø-th neuron just before and after it responds to the current field, respectively.

yi+={yi‚àí¬†if¬†yi‚àí=sign(‚àëj‚â†iwjiyj+bi)‚àíyi‚àío.w. y^+_i = \begin{cases}y_i^- & \text{ if } y^-_i = sign(\sum_{j\neq i} w_{ji} y_j +b_i)\\ - y_i^- & \text{o.w.}\end{cases}yi+‚Äã={yi‚àí‚Äã‚àíyi‚àí‚Äã‚Äã¬†if¬†yi‚àí‚Äã=sign(‚àëjÓÄ†=i‚Äãwji‚Äãyj‚Äã+bi‚Äã)o.w.‚ÄãÔªø.

(yi+‚àíyi‚àí)(‚àëj‚â†iwjiyj+bi)={0¬†if¬†yi+=yi‚àí2yi+(‚àëj‚â†iwjiyj+bi)¬†if¬†yi+=‚àíyi‚àí(y^+_i - y^-_i )\left(\sum_{j\neq i} w_{ji} y_j +b_i\right)= \begin{cases} 0 & \text{ if } y_i^+ = y_i^- \\ 2y^+_i \left(\sum_{j\neq i} w_{ji} y_j +b_i\right) & \text{ if } y_i^+ = -y_i^-\end{cases}(yi+‚Äã‚àíyi‚àí‚Äã)(‚àëjÓÄ†=i‚Äãwji‚Äãyj‚Äã+bi‚Äã)={02yi+‚Äã(‚àëjÓÄ†=i‚Äãwji‚Äãyj‚Äã+bi‚Äã)‚Äã¬†if¬†yi+‚Äã=yi‚àí‚Äã¬†if¬†yi+‚Äã=‚àíyi‚àí‚Äã‚ÄãÔªø

is always positive ‚áí Every flip of a neuron is guaranteed to locally increase.

  • Consider the sum across all nodes

    D(y1,‚Ä¶,yN)=‚àëiyi(‚àëj‚â†iwjiyj+bi)=‚àëi,j‚â†iwjiyiyj+‚àëibiyiD(y_1,\dots,y_N)= \sum_i y_i \left(\sum_{j\neq i} w_{ji} y_j +b_i\right) = \sum_{i,j\neq i} w_{ji} y_iy_j +\sum_i b_i y_iD(y1‚Äã,‚Ä¶,yN‚Äã)=‚àëi‚Äãyi‚Äã(‚àëjÓÄ†=i‚Äãwji‚Äãyj‚Äã+bi‚Äã)=‚àëi,jÓÄ†=i‚Äãwji‚Äãyi‚Äãyj‚Äã+‚àëi‚Äãbi‚Äãyi‚ÄãÔªø

    where we assume wii=0w_{ii} =0wii‚Äã=0Ôªø.

  • For any unit that ‚Äúflips‚Äù because of the local field,
  • DDDÔªø is bounded
    • Dmax‚Å°=‚àëj‚â†i‚à£wji‚à£+‚àëi‚à£bi‚à£D_{\max} = \sum_{j\neq i} | w_{ji}| + \sum_i |b_i|Dmax‚Äã=‚àëjÓÄ†=i‚Äã‚à£wji‚Äã‚à£+‚àëi‚Äã‚à£bi‚Äã‚à£Ôªø
    • ‚à£ŒîDmin‚Å°‚à£=min‚Å°i,{yi,i=1,‚Ä¶,N}2‚à£‚àëj‚â†iwjiyj+bi‚à£|\Delta D_{\min}| = \min_{i,\{y_i, i=1,\dots,N\}} 2 \left\vert \sum_{j\neq i} w_{ji} y_j +b_i \right\vert‚à£ŒîDmin‚Äã‚à£=mini,{yi‚Äã,i=1,‚Ä¶,N}‚Äã2‚Äã‚àëjÓÄ†=i‚Äãwji‚Äãyj‚Äã+bi‚Äã‚ÄãÔªø

    ‚áí Any sequence of flips must converge in a finite number of steps.

  • Energy of a Hopfield net
    • The evolution of a Hopfield network constantly decreases its energy (until some local minimum).
      • For threshold activations the energy contour is only defined on a lattice ‚Äì so yyyÔªø are corners of a unit cube
      • For tanh activations it will be a continuous function (output in [‚àí1,1][-1, 1][‚àí1,1]Ôªø)
      • ‚ÄúEnergy‚Äù contour for a 2-neuron net
        • Two stable states (tanh activation)

          ‚Üí Symmetric, but not at corners

        • Blue arc shows a typical trajectory for tanh activation
      • ‚ÄúEnergy‚Äù contour for a 3-neuron net
        • 8 possible states
        • 2 stable states (for hard thresholded network)
    • Each of the minima is a ‚Äústored‚Äù pattern (stable state) = content addressable memory / associative memory (recall memory content from partial or corrupt values)
      • How do we make the network store a specific pattern or set of patterns?

        ‚Üí How do we teach a network to ‚Äúremember‚Äù an image with N pixels?

        • Need N neurons
        • Every neuron connects to every other neuron
        • N(N‚àí1)2\frac{N(N-1)}{2}2N(N‚àí1)‚ÄãÔªø weights
        • Symmetry: E(P)=E(‚àíP)E(P) = E(-P)E(P)=E(‚àíP)Ôªø for pattern PPPÔªø.
        • Every stable point is a stored pattern ‚áí we could design the net to store multiple patterns
      • How many patterns can we store?
        • Each step rotates the vector and then projects it onto the nearest corner
        • y=sign(Wy)\mathbf{y} = sign(W\mathbf{y})y=sign(Wy)Ôªø ‚áí ‚Äúquantizes‚Äù the space into orthants

        ‚áí Design WWWÔªø such that this holds!!

        • The Eigenvectors of any symmetric matrix WWWÔªø are orthogonal
        • The Eigenvalues may be positive or negative

        y=sign(Wy)=sign(Œªy)=¬±y\mathbf{y} = sign(W\mathbf{y}) = sign(\lambda \mathbf{y}) = \pm \mathbf{y}y=sign(Wy)=sign(Œªy)=¬±yÔªø

        ‚áí we can ‚Äúintentionally‚Äù store up to NN NÔªøpatterns but ‚Ä¶

        • Suppose NNNÔªø eigenvectors {y1,y2,‚Ä¶,yN}\{\mathbf{y_1} ,\mathbf{y_2} ,\dots, \mathbf{y_N} \}{y1‚Äã,y2‚Äã,‚Ä¶,yN‚Äã}Ôªø span the space
        • y=a1y1+‚ãØ+aNyN\mathbf{y} = a_1 \mathbf{y_1} + \dots + a_N \mathbf{y_N}y=a1‚Äãy1‚Äã+‚ãØ+aN‚ÄãyN‚ÄãÔªø for some a1,a2,‚Ä¶,aNa_1, a_2, \dots, a_Na1‚Äã,a2‚Äã,‚Ä¶,aN‚ÄãÔªø such that
        • Maximum number of stationary patterns is actually exponential in NNNÔªø [McElice and Posner, 1984]

        • Number of ways of selecting two
          N_bit binary patterns
          y1\mathbf{y_1} y1‚ÄãÔªø and y2\mathbf{y_2}y2‚ÄãÔªø such that they differ from one another in exactly N2\frac{N}{2}2N‚ÄãÔªø bits is O(23N2)\mathcal{O}\left(2^{\frac{3N}{2}}\right)O(223N‚Äã)Ôªø.
        • The size of the largest set of N-bit binary patterns{y1,y2,‚Ä¶‚Äâ} \{\mathbf{y_1} ,\mathbf{y_2} ,\dots \}{y1‚Äã,y2‚Äã,‚Ä¶}Ôªø that all differ from one another in exactly N2\frac{N}{2}2N‚ÄãÔªø bits is at most NNNÔªø (max NNNÔªø orthogonal vectors in an NNNÔªø-dim space).
        • The fewer memories we store, and the more distant they are, the more likely we are to eliminate spurious memories.
        • For a specific set of KKKÔªø patterns, we can always build a network for which all KKKÔªø patterns are stable provided K‚â§NK‚â§ NK‚â§NÔªø.
          • For large N, the upper bound on KKKÔªø is actually N4log‚Å°N\frac{N}{4\log N}4logNN‚ÄãÔªø [McElice et al. 1987]
          • But this may come with many ‚Äúparasitic‚Äù memories.
      • How to ‚Äúretrieve‚Äù patterns better?
        • Need to estimate WWWÔªø such that EEEÔªø is minimized for target patterns YP={y1,y2,‚Ä¶,yP}\mathbf{Y}_P = \{\mathbf{y_1} ,\mathbf{y_2} ,\dots, \mathbf{y_P} \} YP‚Äã={y1‚Äã,y2‚Äã,‚Ä¶,yP‚Äã}Ôªø and maximized for any other y‚ààÃ∏YP\mathbf{y} \not\in \mathbf{Y}_PyÓÄ†‚ààYP‚ÄãÔªø.
        • Simple gradient descent
          • Do we need to raise everything?
            • If you raise every valley, eventually they‚Äôll all move up above the target patterns, and many will even vanish

            ‚áí Focus on raising the valleys

            • Major requirement: memories must be stable (must be broad valleys)
            • Spurious valleys in the neighborhood of memories are more important to eliminate
          • What if there‚Äôs another target pattern downvalley?

            ‚Üí Raising it will destroy a better-represented or stored pattern!

            • No need to raise the entire surface, or even every valley
            • Raise the neighborhood of each target memory
              • Sufficient to make the memory a valley
              • The broader the neighborhood considered, the broader the valley
        • How do we increase the capacity of the network?

          where in hidden neurons, actual values are not important!

          What patterns do we fill in the hidden bits (in total of 2K2^K2KÔªø patterns)?

          ‚Üí Randomly: Flip a coin for each bit

          • We could even compose multiple extended patterns for a base pattern to increase the probability that it will be recalled properly
          • Recalling any of the extended patterns from a base pattern will recall the base pattern

          How do we store the patterns?
          ‚Üí Standard optimization method to learn
          WWWÔªø.

          Capacity: ‚àº(N+K)\sim(N+K)‚àº(N+K)Ôªø patterns

          • Although we only care about the pattern of the first NNNÔªø neurons
          • Maximum number of patterns the net can store is bounded by the width N of the patterns.

          How do we retrieve a memory?

          • Using usual ‚Äúevolution‚Äù mechanism
            ‚Üí Not taking advantage of a key feature of the extended
            patterns.
          • Value taken by the K hidden neurons during recall
            doesn‚Äôt really matter (making error here doesn‚Äôt matter)
          • We can have multiple extended patterns with the same pattern over visible bits

          ‚Üí May have multiple hidden patterns for a target pattern (multiple valleys, in which the visible bits remain the same, but hidden bits vary)

A probabilistic interpretation of Hopfield Nets

  • For binary y\mathbf{y}yÔªø, the energy of a pattern = negative log likelihood of a Boltzmann distribution
    • The Boltzman distribution P(y)=Cexp‚Å°(‚àíE(y)kT)P(\mathbf{y})= C \exp \left( \frac{- E(\mathbf{y})}{kT}\right)P(y)=Cexp(kT‚àíE(y)‚Äã)Ôªø
      • kkkÔªø is the Boltzmann constant
      • TTTÔªø is the temperature of the system
      • C=1‚àëyexp‚Å°(‚àíE(y)kT)C = \frac{1}{\sum_{\mathbf{y}} \exp \left( \frac{-E(\mathbf{y})}{kT}\right)}C=‚àëy‚Äãexp(kT‚àíE(y)‚Äã)1‚ÄãÔªø.
    • The system probabilistically selects states with lower energy - with infinitesimally slow cooling, at T=0T=0T=0Ôªø, it arrives at the global minimal state.
    • Selecting a next state = drawing a sample from the Boltzmann distribution at T=1T=1T=1Ôªø, in a universe where k=1k=1k=1Ôªø.
  • Minimizing energy ‚áî\Leftrightarrow‚áîÔªø maximizes log likelihood
  • Optimizing WWWÔªø using GD

    where Œ±y\alpha_{\mathbf{y}} Œ±y‚ÄãÔªørepresents the weight for more frequently presented memories, Œ≤(E(y))\beta(E(\mathbf{y}))Œ≤(E(y))Ôªø represents weight to more attractive spurious memories.

  • The Helmholtz Free Energy of a system
    • A thermodynamic system at temperature TTTÔªø can exist in one of many states
      • Potentially infinite states
      • At any time, the probability of finding the system in state sssÔªø at temperature is PT(s)P_T(s)PT‚Äã(s)Ôªø
    • At each state sssÔªø, it has a potential energy EsE_sEs‚ÄãÔªø
    • The internal energy (capacity to do work) of the system is the average
    • The capacity to do work is counteracted by the internal disorder of the system, i.e. its entropy
    • The Helmholtz free energy of the system combines the two terms

      ‚Üí A system held at a specific temperature anneals by varying the rate at which it visits the various states, to reduce the free energy in the system, until a minimum free-energy state is achieved.

      ‚Üí The probability distribution of the states at steady state is known as the Boltzmann distribution.

      ‚Üí Minimize FTF_TFT‚ÄãÔªø w.r.t PT(s)P_T(s)PT‚Äã(s)Ôªø, we get PT(s)=1Zexp‚Å°(‚àíEskT)P_T(s) = \frac{1}{Z} \exp \left(\frac{-E_s}{kT} \right)PT‚Äã(s)=Z1‚Äãexp(kT‚àíEs‚Äã‚Äã)Ôªø

      • Known as the Gibbs distribution
      • ZZZÔªø is a normalizing constant
      • Note the dependence on TT TÔªø
      • At T=0T = 0T=0Ôªø, the system will always remain at the lowest energy configuration with probability = 1.
  • The stochastic Hopfield network models a probability distribution over states = Boltzmann machine (a generative model) generates states according to P(S)P(S)P(S)Ôªø
    • Deterministic Hopfield network: learn weights to ‚Äúremember‚Äù target states and ‚Äúdislike‚Äù other states (‚ÄúState‚Äù SSSÔªø == binary pattern of all the neurons)
    • Boltzmann machine: learn weights to assign a desired probability distribution to states
    • The parameters of the model are the weights of the network
    • The probability that (at equilibrium) the network will be in any state is P(S)P(S) P(S)Ôªø

    • Models a Boltzmann distribution
    • log‚Å°P(S)=‚àíE(S)+C\log P(S) = - E(S) + ClogP(S)=‚àíE(S)+CÔªø

    • The field at a single node
      • Let SSSÔªø and S‚ÄôS‚ÄôS‚ÄôÔªø be identical states (y1,‚Ä¶,yi,‚Ä¶,yN)(y_1, \dots, y_i, \dots, y_N)(y1‚Äã,‚Ä¶,yi‚Äã,‚Ä¶,yN‚Äã)Ôªø that only differ in the iiiÔªø-th bit

        i.e. suppose yi={1,yi‚ààS‚àí1,yi‚ààS‚Äôy_i = \begin{cases} 1, & y_i \in S \\-1, & y_i\in S‚Äô\end{cases}yi‚Äã={1,‚àí1,‚Äãyi‚Äã‚ààSyi‚Äã‚ààS‚Äô‚ÄãÔªø

      where E(S)=‚àí12(E‚â†i+‚àëj‚â†iwjiyj+bi)E(S) = -\frac{1}{2} \left(E_{\neq i} + \sum_{j\neq i} w_{ji} y_j + b_i \right)E(S)=‚àí21‚Äã(EÓÄ†=i‚Äã+‚àëjÓÄ†=i‚Äãwji‚Äãyj‚Äã+bi‚Äã)Ôªø,

      E(S‚Äô)=‚àí12(E‚â†i‚àí‚àëj‚â†iwjiyj‚àíbi)E(S‚Äô) = -\frac{1}{2} \left(E_{\neq i} - \sum_{j\neq i} w_{ji} y_j -b_i \right)E(S‚Äô)=‚àí21‚Äã(EÓÄ†=i‚Äã‚àí‚àëjÓÄ†=i‚Äãwji‚Äãyj‚Äã‚àíbi‚Äã)Ôªø

    • Evolution of a stochastic Hopfield net

      ‚Üí Let the system evolve to ‚Äúequilibrium‚Äù

      • Let y0,‚Ä¶,yL\mathbf{y}_0, \dots, \mathbf{y}_Ly0‚Äã,‚Ä¶,yL‚ÄãÔªø be the sequence of values
      • Final predicted configuration: from the average of the final few iterations
        • If the probability that yi=1y_i = 1 yi‚Äã=1Ôªø is greater than 0.50.50.5Ôªø, sets yi=1y_i =1yi‚Äã=1Ôªø
      • Include a temperature term in computing the local field to improve the likelihood of finding good (or optimal) minimum-energy state
        • At T=‚àûT = \inftyT=‚àûÔªø, the energy ‚Äúsurface‚Äù will be flat.
        • At T=1 T = 1T=1Ôªø, surface will be the usual energy surface.
        • At T=0T = 0T=0Ôªø, we get deterministic Hopfield behavior.
  • Training the Boltzmann machine = maximize likelihood of stored states

    where states S=(y1,y2,‚Ä¶,yN)S = (y_1, y_2, \dots, y_N)S=(y1‚Äã,y2‚Äã,‚Ä¶,yN‚Äã)Ôªø‚ààS \in \mathbf{S}‚ààSÔªø

    • We cannot compute the exact value of (2)(2)(2)Ôªø since it is summed over all training states, but we can estimate it via sampling!
    • How do we draw samples from the Boltzmann distribution?
      • Initialize the network randomly and let it ‚Äúevolve‚Äù‚Üí probabilistically selecting state values according to our model
      • After many many epochs, take a snapshot of the state
      • Repeat this many many times
      • Let the collection of states be Ssim={Ssim,1,‚Ä¶,Ssim,M}\mathbf{S}_{sim} = \{S_{sim,1},\dots, S_{sim,M}\}Ssim‚Äã={Ssim,1‚Äã,‚Ä¶,Ssim,M‚Äã}Ôªø

      ‚áí gradient ascent of the weight using the sampled likelihood estimate

  • Training the Boltzmann machine with hidden neurons
    • S=(V,H)S = (V,H)S=(V,H)Ôªø where V=V =V=Ôªø visible bits, H=H =H=Ôªø hidden bits
    • We are interested in the marginal probabilities over visible bits
      • Want to learn to represent the visible bits
      • The hidden bits are the ‚Äúlatent‚Äù representation learned by the network
  • Train a network to maximize likelihood of desired patterns of visible bits
    • Repeat K times to generate synthetic training data
      • For each training pattern ViV_iVi‚ÄãÔªø, fix the visible units to ViV_iVi‚ÄãÔªø
        • Let the hidden neurons evolve from a random initial point to generate HiH_iHi‚ÄãÔªø
        • Generate Si=(Vi,Hi)S_i =(V_i,H_i)Si‚Äã=(Vi‚Äã,Hi‚Äã)Ôªø
    • Unclamp the visible units and let the entire network evolve several times to generate
    • Applications
      • Filling out patterns
        • ‚ÄúAnchor‚Äù the known visible units
        • Let the network evolve
        • Sample the unknown visible units & choose the most probable value
      • Denoising patterns
      • Computing conditional probabilities of patterns
      • Classification!!

        Training patterns: [s1,s2,‚Ä¶,¬†class][s_1, s_2, \dots, \text{ class}][s1‚Äã,s2‚Äã,‚Ä¶,¬†class]Ôªø

        • Features can have binarized or continuous valued representations
        • Classes have ‚Äúone hot‚Äù representation

        ‚Üí Given features, anchor features, estimate a posteriori probability distribution over classes (or choose most likely class)

    • Issues
      • Training takes for ever
      • Doesn‚Äôt really work for large problems (only works well on a small number of training instances over a small number of bits)

      ‚áí Restricted Boltzmann machine (RBM)

      Recall Boltzmann machine:
      • Still obeys the same rules as a regular Boltzmann machine
      • But the modified structure adds a big benefit.
      • Excellent generative models for binary (or binarized) data

      Visible units only talk to hidden units

      Hidden units only talk to visible units

      Other variants:

      • Continuous-values RBMs

        P(vi)=r(yi)exp‚Å°(yi)P(v_i) = r(y_i) \exp(y_i)P(vi‚Äã)=r(yi‚Äã)exp(yi‚Äã)Ôªø

      • ‚ÄúDeep‚Äù Boltzmann machines
      • Helmholtz machine (trained by the ‚Äúwake-sleep‚Äù algorithm)

      ‚Üí Training RBM

      • No looping!!
      • For each sample, iteratively sample hidden and visible units for a long time (anchor visible units and samples from hidden units, then repeat vice versa)
      • Draw final sample of both hidden and visible unit
Towards Rapid Design of Dexterous and Agile Robotic Behavior

(Guest lecture: Pulkit Agrawal, MIT)

  • How to design behaviors for complex task in less structured settings (such as robots)?
    • succeed in understanding (e.g. need a sponge to clean the spill) - common sense knowledge from LLMs
    • failed in low-level execution (e.g. use the sponge to clean the spill itself) ‚Üí don‚Äôt have enough data
  • Designing robot behaviors is not scalable

Goal: how to quickly and easily design diverse & complex behaviors that work in less structured settings?

  • Manipulation (e.g. grasping objects) - no motions between objects & fingers
  • Automating hands - need frequent & breaking of contacts between objects & fingers
    • Continuous-discrete optimization ‚Üí hard to solve/ slow inference
    • Main challenge when design controller for tasks beyond grasping
      • Made simplifications: simple object shapes or smaller motion range

      ‚Üí restricted finger motion (easier optimization but lack of generality)

‚áí want: general orientation system with complex shapes & generalizable

Dexterous manipulation

  • Simulations to Reality is a powerful paradigm for contact-rich tasks.
